entry.title: The Question of Full Loading Large CDS VIews from S/4 HANA: Problems and Solutions
entry.content:
Introduction

It‚Äôs no secret that many companies today have large, or even massive, datasets in S/4 HANA systems that need to be uploaded to SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere or SLT. A prime example of this is the CDS View I_GLAccountLineItemRawData, which consume data from the ACDOCA table. There are known cases where the ACDOCA table exceeds 10 billion records. This article will discuss the problems that arise when transferring such large datasets and explore potential solutions.

In my previous article, I mentioned that the first step in the initial data load procedure is the calculation of "Access Plans". This is necessary to speed up the data loading process by parallelizing the processes. Each access plan is a specific range of records, defined by the object‚Äôs key fields. The size of this range is set during start of replication and varies for different scenarios. For example, in a BDC scenario, the default size of a single portion is 500 megabytes, for SAP Datasphere Replication Flows size portion is 30 megabytes. Since one access plan consists of 100 portions, the size of an access plan is approximately 50 gigabytes for BDC scenario and 3 gigabytes for Replication Flows. 

Note: above mentioned size is the size of data representation in ABAP runtime.

The Access Plan Calculation process itself consists of two phases: pre-calculation (aka delimitation) and calculation of access plans. The pre-calculation process divides the entire dataset into large chunks, which are known as "access plans". The calculation process reads the data within the calculated boundaries, divides it into portions, and writes these portions to a special intermediate buffer. Immediately after the calculation of one access plan is complete, a transfer process for that access plan is initiated. Optimization in  the access plan calculation process is achieved because, after the pre-calculation phase, each access plan is calculated in a separate process, and the number of these processes is limited only by service settings, system power, and allocated computing resources.

The main problem for very large CDS Views arises during the pre-calculation process. During pre-calculation, the process reads all sorted key fields of all records from the CDS View once to determine the boundaries of the access plans. This is where problems can occur due to the limitations imposed by the HANA database. There are several limitations:

- First, HANA DB imposes a limit on the number of records returned in a single query ‚Äì it cannot exceed 2 billion records.
- Second, there is a parameter that defines the memory size allocated by HANA DB for a single session. The query can exceed the memory allocated for one session.
- Third, overflow can also occur if HANA DB does not build query plans optimally enough.
In such cases, the object gets stuck in the "Error in Delimitation Process" status, which you can observe in the DHADM tool, in the "Access Plan Calculation Overview" section. In this case, you need to choose the optimal solution strategy and restart the object upload.

So, what solutions are available to address these problems? First, I will briefly list them, and then I will describe each approach in more detail:

  1. If a session runs out of memory, the simplest and most obvious solution is to increase the session memory limit provided to each session.
  2. If the CDS View contains simple left outer join or simple select from a table with more than 2 billion records, then database partitions are used during pre-calculation process.
  3. If the main table of the CDS View is partitioned, it may be possible to use special hints that will help HANA DB build query plans efficiently.
  4. If previous recommendations do not help, it is suggested to use the ranges functionality, provided in DHADM tool.

Unfortunately, there is no universal solution to these problems; each option has its pros and cons, involves certain complexities in implementation, and has some limitations. You must independently decide which approach will be the most optimal for a given dataset to solve the problem.

 

1. Increasing the Session Memory Limit Size in HANA DB

The official documentation on the SAP Help Portal contains detailed information on "Setting a Memory Limit for SQL Statements": 
On the portal, you will find recommendations for the allocated memory sizes and how to change the parameter value.
 
However, it should be kept in mind that increasing the session memory limit can only help if the number of records in the CDS View does not exceed 2 billion records.
Although this method helps in most cases, it's still has limits, it may have to be combined with the solution described below.
 
Practical Example:
The buffer size was set to 341 GB. And although, according to expert assessment by HANA DB specialists, this value is very large, this size was still not sufficient to execute the query from the I_GLAccountLineItemRawData CDS View.
It is potentially possible to continue increasing the parameter value further, but it is still recommended to look for other ways to solve the problem.
 

2. Utilizing Physical Partitioning of the Main Table at the HANA DB Level

This option provides a solution when the CDS View contains more than 2 billion records. Usually, such CDS View is built on partitioned table. Using physical partitioning the pre-calculation process divides the table into large blocks. 
The calculation of Access Plans will be performed within each partition separately, independently of each other. By the way, in this case, the pre-calculation process will also be accelerated because it is performed in several parallel processes.

Picture 1. Access plan calculation concept

Please note that pre-calculation will only use the partitions created for the main table. The role of the main table must be described in the dataExtraction annotation within the CDS View or can be determined automatically in simple cases. Example CDS View: I_GLAccountLineItemRawData:

      dataExtraction: {
        enabled: true,
        delta.changeDataCapture: {
          mapping:
            [
              {
                table: 'ACDOCA',
                role: #MAIN,
                viewElement: ['SourceLedger', 'CompanyCode', 'FiscalYear', 'AccountingDocument', 'LedgerGLLineItem'],
                tableElement: ['rldnr', 'rbukrs', 'gjahr', 'belnr', 'docln']
              }
            ]
         }
      }

Code 1. Example of CDS Annotation with declaration of MAIN table


For example, for the ACDOCA table, there is SAP Note 2289491, which provides best practice recommendations.

Nevertheless, there are examples where this does not help, and the error persists. In this case, you can try supplementing the solution with the first option (increasing buffer) and/or the next option using DB hints.

 

3. Utilizing HANA DB Hints

 
If you are the owner of the CDS View (and have control over the code), you can use HANA recommendations and apply database hints directly in CDS View to help the database build query plans more efficiently. Or you can apply hint to existing SQL statement.
 
@Consumption.dbHints: ['USE_HEX_PLAN']
An article from the official SAP Help Portal containing detailed information on "Performance Aspects of Specific Features" where you can find a description of the hint.
Note: To activate database hint support in CDC, SAP Note 3701822 must be installed.
 
This method is recommended to be used in conjunction with table partitioning. This can help save memory and stay within the allocated buffer for a single session.
 
 
Practical Example:
In continuation of the first practical example, it's not possible to apply a hint to the SAP owned CDS View which cannot be changed.
In such case it is necessary to find the hash value of pre-calculation query (for example, using the search in DBACOCKPIT->Performance->Expensive Statements). The pre-calculation statement looks like:
 
SELECT /* Contains Native SQL */ "SOURCELEDGER" , "COMPANYCODE" , "FISCALYEAR" , "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" , "LEDGERGLLINEITEM" FROM /* Entity name: I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMRAWDATA WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS */ "IFIGLACCTLIR" "A" WHERE "MANDT" = ? AND "FISCALYEAR" = ? AND EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM "ACDOCA" PARTITION (10) WHERE "ACDOCA" . "RCLNT" = ? AND "ACDOCA" . "RLDNR" = "A" . "SOURCELEDGER" AND "ACDOCA" . "RBUKRS" = "A" . "COMPANYCODE" AND "ACDOCA" . "GJAHR" = "A" . "FISCALYEAR" AND "ACDOCA" . "BELNR" = "A" . "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" AND "ACDOCA" . "DOCLN" = "A" . "LEDGERGLLINEITEM" ) ORDER BY "A" . "SOURCELEDGER" , "A" . "COMPANYCODE" , "A" . "FISCALYEAR" , "A" . "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" , "A" . "LEDGERGLLINEITEM"
 
And execute the following command:,
 
ALTER SYSTEM ADD STATEMENT HINT ( USE_HEX_PLAN ) FOR STATEMENT HASH '2e23331ec91cbc6b803aa477ec4538d9';
 

4. Usage of Range Conditions Functionality

Even so, it may happen that all the previously described methods do not solve the problem. There is another method, which is very similar to partitioning - Range Conditions in DHADM transaction.

Ranges are the division of the entire dataset into parts, same to database partitions, but it is performed only for pre-calculation during initial load process. The advantages of this approach are:

- Ranges can be defined independent from database partitions.
- Ranges can break down data into smaller portions than partitions.
- When using ranges, the SQL query has a simpler form, and HANA DB significantly optimizes this type of query.
Here, I want to describe several questions that arise when using Range Conditions.

a. Are Range Conditions applied only during Initial Load?
Yes, ranges are applied and used only for the initial snapshot load. During the delta phase, ranges no longer play any role.

b. Is it possible to use Range Conditions for data filtering?
Yes, it is possible, but strongly not recommended.
First, based on the previous point - filters based on ranges will only be applied for the initial load. Delta data will not be filtered. And secondly, you must always remember that the ranges are defined the in scope of current client and CDS View. This means that if you want to load the same CDS View with different "filters", you will not be able to. The same set of "filters" will always be used. To filter data, it is recommended to use the mechanisms provided by various scenarios. For example, SLT and Datasphere offer the ability to defined filters when setup replication. The BDC scenario does not provide filter capability.

c. What operations are supported in the definition of range conditions?
All standard logical comparison operations, as well as AND/OR and BETWEEN.
Do not forget to define ranges correctly, especially open boundary range conditions. There should be no gaps in the definition. It is recommended to make the boundary intervals open to avoid data loss. For example:

 interval 1: key1 < 1000
 interval 2: 1000 <= key1 < 5000
  ...
 interval N: key1 >= 100,000

Code 2. Example of range boundaries

During save Range conditions will be analyzed for syntax errors. Logical errors in the definition (e.g., overlapping ranges or gap in range conditions) will not be checked and remain with the user. 

d. Who should define and maintain ranges, and what is the optimal strategy in defining ranges?
We cannot give you any particular recommendation how to define range conditions. Each client independently defines the ranges according to their needs and data content.
Analyze your data structure, look at which key fields do not change very often so that you can use them as a basis for dividing the data, and see how evenly the data is distributed across these values.
By the way, in the first option, you can use the same conditions that are proposed for database partitioning. Since, as already mentioned, another simplified form of the SQL query is used for ranges, there is a possibility that these ranges will solve the problem.

e. How to create Range conditions?
One of the drawbacks is that ranges must be defined manually, range by range, using the DHADM UI.

Add new range via DHADM UI

Picture 2. How to add new Range manually via DHADM UI

However, by installing SAP Note 3670148, a simpler way to support ranges is offered, which also allows you to migrate ranges between systems.

You need to create an file with the specific structure. The file‚Äôs structure should follow the specifications outlined in the note. The descriptor file can contain range conditions for multiple CDS Views.

After creating such a file, it must be uploaded to the system via the DHADM UI. During the upload, all ranges will be analyzed for syntax errors. Logical errors in the definition (e.g., overlapping ranges or gap in range conditions) will not be checked and remain with the user! Attention: when uploading ranges, the previous definition will be overwritten. After uploading, you can change and correct the ranges using the built-in UI or by changing the source file to repeat the upload.

If you have defined or corrected ranges in the test system, you can export all ranges to a file and transfer them to the production system.

[
	{
		"cdsviewname": "I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMRAWDATA",
		"ranges": [
			{
				"id": 1,
				"condition": "FiscalYear < '2021'"
			},
			{
				"id": 2,
				"condition": "FiscalYear >= '2021' and FiscalYear < '2022'"
			}
		]
	}
]

Code 3. Example of JSON file for CDS View I_GLAccountLineItemRawData

Upload/Download ranges

Picture 3. Upload or download ranges for one or several CDS Views


Similar to partitions, access plans will be calculated for each range separately. Similar to the option with partitions, the pre-calculation process will also be performed in parallel for each range.
The most important rule: all operations must be performed before the start of the load. Existing subscriptions do not take ranges into account in the pre-calculation process.

entry.title: BW vs. Datasphere (DSP) & SAC
entry.content:
From a functional and development perspective, SAP BW and the combination of Datasphere (DSP) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) represent two different generations of SAP‚Äôs data & analytics stack.

  • BW is feature‚Äërich and comes with many out‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëbox capabilities: tightly integrated data warehousing, mature modeling, and predefined mechanisms for enhancements and reporting.
  • DSP/SAC provides a leaner programming and configuration set, which often requires a ‚Äúdo‚Äëit‚Äëyourself‚Äù approach: more scripting, more custom logic, and more architectural decisions on the customer side.

However, DSP/SAC are actively and rapidly evolving. Each release brings new features‚Äîand sometimes new issues, especially in SAC‚Äîbut the overall trajectory clearly indicates that DSP/SAC are the strategic future. Over the long term, the flexibility, cloud‚Äënative approach, and continuous innovation of DSP & SAC are expected to outgrow and eventually surpass BW in capability and relevance.

How-To implement BW functionality in DSP/SAC

Architecture DSP https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-architecture-and-security-concept/ba-p/13702030

BW Security like in DSP/SAC https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-like-authorizations-in-datasphere-dsp/ba-p/14153918

Generic-like extraction into DSP https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-delta-extraction/ba-p/13699391

BW to DSP extraction using ODP https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-bw-odp-delta-via-replication-flow/ba-p/13739830

BW BEx User/Customer Exit https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/how-to-build-bw-user-customer-exits-in-datasphere-dsp-sac/ba-p/14290016#M176749

DSP and SAC Versioning & Backup and Restore https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/datasphere-dsp-and-sac-data-and-metadata-versioning-backup-and-restore/ba-p/14291938#M176814

entry.title: How-To build BW BEx User/Customer Exits in Datasphere (DSP) / SAC
entry.content:
Basic:

In traditional SAP BW, User/Customer Exits allow for centrally managed code that applies to all BEx queries. An efficient, object-oriented approach. This functionality can be built via SAC's Composite Widgets (CW). The main / common functions such as ISO-week, Fiscal YearPeriod, Project specific functions, can be placed into a single / multiple CWs. These CWs will be added to Stories and the Stories can use the CWs ‚Äì Interfaces (Public-like Methods). CWs use also own functions (Private-like Methods). This approach allows to have all the functions in one place.

 

Use cases:

This solution can be used to centralize and standardize various functions across multiple SAC stories, including:

  • A universal on/off switch for JavaScript logging. Logs are critical for troubleshooting, but also slow down the processing a bit and can provide unwanted details to end-users.
  • A custom function to calculate the ISO Week (not supported by default in SAC optimized stories).
  • Automatic calculation of the current fiscal period based on the current date.
  • A global "maintenance switch" to manage functionalities during version rollouts. Possible to route to an Out-Of-Order Story.
  • Displaying the data loading status from Datasphere.

 

How-To:

  • Create a composite (e.g. COMMON_FUNCTIONS) and move common JavaScript and functions from individual stories into this composite.
  • Expose functionality via interfaces (public) and keep helper logic as Functions (private methods) inside the composite.
  • Add the composite to each required story/page via drag & drop, hide it at design/runtime, and call its interfaces as if they were local story functions.
  • For configuration/switches (similar to TVARVC/P-tables), use SAC acquired models‚Äîoptionally loaded from DSP via OData‚Äîfor better performance than live connections.
  • Be aware of library limits inside composites (e.g. Application.getUser()), and pass required context (user, filters, etc.) from the story into the composite.

Possible only with SAC (native or seamless) planning:

Direct write-back from a Story (f.e. last used prompt). This part is not covered as planning is usually limited in SAC due to extra licensing as in BW/4.

 

Main blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-vs-datasphere-dsp-amp-sac/ba-p/14289847

entry.title: How to Learn SAP Datasphere ‚Äì The Cloud-Based Data Warehouse / Data Fabric Solution
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere plays a major role within SAP Business Data Cloud, our new data analytics platform.

 

SAP Datasphere is also a full-grown powerful data fabric / data warehouse solution on its own.

 

It provides graphical and pro-code options for data harmonization and integration. It is SAP‚Äôs strategic solution for this purpose.

 

 

You can even integrate native SAP HANA models (For details about these models, read Jan ZWICKEL‚Äôs blog about SAP HANA Calculation views).

In this community, you will find blogs and other resources on SAP Datasphere. As this is a highly dynamic topic with a new wave every 2 weeks, please check regularly for updates. Feel free to ask questions. Please feel free to use this new community and connect with us and other learners.

Your feedback on these resources is highly welcome. Also let us know about topics you would like to have covered in future live sessions and blogs, so that we can make our content even more suited to your needs.

So, how can you take up knowledge about SAP Datasphere and prove it?

 

Learning about SAP Datasphere

  • If you want to find a short overview, the 3 hour online course Exploring SAP Datasphere suits you best. Search for DSPE01 on https://learning.sap.com.
  • If you need information about the cloud-based SAP BW/4HANA tenant called SAP Datasphere, SAP BW bridge, we offer the 4 hour online course SAP Datasphere, SAP BW Bridge.

 

 

 

 What if you want to practice?

Here again, we have nice courses for you!

  • The SAP Datasphere Overview  (online tour offers a complementary system. (Search for TRIAL_INT_DSP_OVERVIEW on https://learning.sap.com.)

 

 

 

  • If you want to dive deeper and ask questions, book the instructor-led DSP01 - Introduction to SAP Datasphere | SAP Training. Create your own models in several hands-on exercises based on 3 typical scenarios: file upload for self-service, fuzzy data matching, data harmonization from 3 different sources. (Search for DSP01 on https://training.sap.com)

 

 

 

Live Sessions

In addition to courses and practice systems, the SAP Learning portal offers live sessions that are useful to go keep learning, ask questions, deepen your knowledge on specific topics. These sessions are delivered by subject-matter-experts (SMEs), either from SAP Training, SAP Partners or other experts at SAP such as Product Managers.

The sessions come under five categories:

  • Get Started
  • Expert Deep Dive
  • What's New
  • Get Certified
  • Stay Certified

Some of the live sessions are available for free, some require a subscription. This is visible in the example below:

SAP Datasphere Live Session catalog sample on SAP Learning 

For example, we offer topics on Graphical Modeling for SAP Analytics Cloud, Performance Optimization for Backend Modelling and SAC Stories.

 

Want to prove your knowledge and increase your value?

When you feel prepared enough, you should take the certification.

SAP Datasphere is part of the AI-based practice certification C_BDCBC.

 

Happy learning with SAP!

entry.title: Datasphere (DSP) and SAC data and metadata versioning / backup and restore
entry.content:
Background:

Contrary to BW f.e. where full Versioning of all objects is available. Data backup directly of requests on the file-system/logical path (not SARA, but also SARA can be used). DSP and SAC have no such out-of-the-box solutions (except a handful of DSP objects). 

SAC: offers no Versioning nor Data protection 

DSP: Versioning exists for: Tables (including Remote), Views, Models, Task Chains, DACs, Replication Flows, Transformation Flows. Restore is possible only for: Tables (local only, not remote), Views, and Models. What is not versioned at all: Data Flows.

 

What exists is: Full DB backups (DB-Snapshots with RedoLogs) - Platform Backup: 

SAP: 

  • DSP and SAC Tenants: SAP creates a daily backup with 15-minute intervals for RedoLogs, but this is for disaster recovery and is not available to customers. These backups are retained for 14 days.
  • SAP HANA Cloud offers Back/Restore of the entire DB (daily plus 15-minutes RedoLogs) for 1-215 days.

3rd party (DB-snapshots):

  • Data Lakehouse (Databricks) - Connect Databricks and integrate the data into the Amazon S3 layer. Use Amazon BackUp feature, but full DB. 
  • Google's Data Cloud - Same as Databricks, but data will be in stored on Google servers instead of Amazon S3.

 

Solution/steps:

SAP Suggests pushing the data to a separate tenant - requires more admin overhead and added costs for the 'backup' tenant or creating content packages with data. 

 

Alternatives for Data backup:

#1 Push data via Replication Flow into a separated DB (create a connection to own DB / costs compared to S3, Google, separated DSP tenant are negligible). Replication Flow can export data (this is the PI/EAI/EDI functionality of DSP), Replication flows may require additional costs, but backups can be run during off-peak hours.

#2 Pull data via OData to separate DB (f.e. Azure Data Factory - create Linked Service, Create Connection, where you specify the DSP Space.View/Table, create Dataset and 'SINK' the data - suggestion is to drop and recreate the table to avoid errors when the DSP view/table structure changes)

#3 Store data in local tables - These tables would be in a separate space. Tables need to be set to disk (not in-memory), as you do not want the memory footprint to be expanded unnecessary. Least efficient alternative. 

SAC Planning data can be pushed to DSP via CDI connection (if Native is used) and then backed-up. In case of Seamless planning, the data is already in DSP stored. SAC Actuals data are expected to be acquired from DSP in our case. 

 

Alternatives for Metadata backup:

DSP and SAC via transport files -> Via CLI an automated script can be created (as of now there is no automated export job available). 

DSP offers versioning for: Tables (including Remote), Views, Models, Task Chains, DACs, Replication Flows, Transformation Flows. What is not versioned at all: Data Flows. 

 

Restore: 

SAC -> transport files. Just re-deploy into your DEV tenant and thus 'restore' the f.e. Story in the version you need. Helps a lot as complex stories with complex Java-Scripting tent to get corrupt - f.e. lose the model information. 

DSP -> Restore is possible only for: Tables (local only, not remote), Views, and Models. Everything else is only transport files. 

're-transport' is also possible from TST or PROD tenants back to DEV tenant of course.

 

References

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/0c3780ad05fd417fa27b98418535debd/ae2b2b7117c84b0aab670ddd2f...

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud/sap-hana-cloud-administration-guide/backup-and-recovery

https://me.sap.com/notes/3491324

https://me.sap.com/notes/3574161

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/43509d67b8b84e66a30851e832f66911/586699519c83489bb778878236...

 

Main blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-vs-datasphere-dsp-amp-sac/ba-p/1428...

entry.title: Data masking, data scrambling and data anonymization in Business Data Cloud with SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • 1 - Generalities
  • 1.1 - Data masking
  • 1.2 - Data scrambling
  • 1.2.1 - Create function
  • 1.2.2 - Expose table data
  • 1.2.3 - Create a view
  • 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere
  • 1.3 - Data anonymization
  • 2 - Standardization
  • 2.1 - Parameters table
  • 2.2 - SQL Procedures
  • 2.2.1 - Procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT
  • 2.2.2 - Procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR
  • 2.2.3 - Procedure EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR
  • 2.3 - Task Chain
  • 2.3.1 - Grant permissions
  • 2.3.2 - Create a task chain
  • 2.3.3 - Test
  • Conclusion

 

Introduction

This blog post was inspired from: How Data Anonymization in SAP HANA secure Generative AI applications through SAP Datasphere 

Here you will find a description of generalities about:

  • masking, scrambling and anonymization features
  • how to automate the creation of views with data masking, data scrambling and data anonymization and the possibility to activate/deactivate some features in the target views.

SAP Datasphere contains a lot of features. Some are accessible directly via its user interface and others are accessible via Open SQL Schema (see SAP Datasphere help site). Open SQL Schema gives you access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud database, and extends the capacities offered via Datasphere's UI.

In this blog, we use a Datasphere space called DEMO with the database user DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE.

We will use a Datasphere local table SALARY as an example dataset where we would like to:

  • mask the CREDIT_CARD column and rename the column to CREDIT_CARD_MASKED,
  • scramble the NAME column and rename the column to NAME_SCRAMBLED,
  • anonymize the SALARY column and rename the column to SALARY_ANONYMIZED

 

 

Note: SALARY column data type is Double.

Save the content below to import a sample dataset into the SALARY local table.

"ID","NAME","GENDER","CITY","SALARY","CREDIT_CARD"
"1","Paul McCartney","M","Levallois","1002.32","1111-1111-1111-1111"
"2","Martin Solveig","M","Munich","3218.21","2222-2222-2222-2222"
"3","Nils Lofgren","M","Nice","1398.32","3333-3333-3333-3333"
"4","Annika","F","Munich","2053.23","4444-4444-4444-4444"

 

1 - Generalities

1.1 - Data masking

Data masking is a feature implemented into SAP HANA Cloud (see Data Masking).
In this blog, we will not use privileges to manage masking, but simply use calculated SQL expressions when defining views where some columns should be masked.

To mask the content of the NAME column, we can just use the following SQL Statement into an SQL view object in Datasphere :

SELECT "ID",
   "NAME",
   CITY,
   GENDER,
   SALARY,
   LEFT(CREDIT_CARD, 4) || '-XXXX-XXXX-' || RIGHT(CREDIT_CARD, 4) AS CREDIT_CARD_MASKED
FROM SALARY

The content displayed by the view is:

 

1.2 - Data scrambling

To scramble characters in a string, a function needs to be created in the Open SQL Schema DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE (the one automatically created by Datasphere when creating the database user). To connect to this schema, SAP HANA Database Explorer can be started from the space management window:

 

1.2.1 - Create function

Once in data Database explorer, the function SCRAMBLE_STRING can be created:

Copy/Paste the following code:

CREATE FUNCTION SCRAMBLE_STRING (IN input NVARCHAR(500))
RETURNS scrambled NVARCHAR(500)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE len INT = LENGTH(:input);
    DECLARE temp NVARCHAR(500) = :input;
    DECLARE result NVARCHAR(500) = '';
    DECLARE pos INT;
 
    WHILE LENGTH(:temp) > 0 DO
        pos := CEIL(RAND() * LENGTH(:temp));  -- Pick random position
        result := result || SUBSTRING(:temp, :pos, 1); -- Append character
        temp := REPLACE(:temp, SUBSTRING(:temp, :pos, 1), ''); -- Remove picked char
    END WHILE;
 
    scrambled := result;
  END

1.2.2 - Expose table data

Since Datasphere local tables cannot be directly exposed, in order to be able to read the content of the SALARY table when using an Open SQL Schema, a view V_SALARY needs to be created in Datasphere using the Data Builder:

SELECT "ID",
	"NAME",
	"GENDER",
	"CITY",
	"SALARY",
	"CREDIT_CARD"
FROM "SALARY"

1.2.3 - Create a view

A view V_SALARY_SCRAMBLED can now be created using Database Explorer to scramble the column NAME from the  V_SALARY view (the call to INITCAP function was just added to format names):

CREATE VIEW "V_SALARY_NAME_SCRAMBLED" AS
(SELECT 
	"ID" AS "ID",
	INITCAP(SCRAMBLE_STRING("NAME")) AS NAME_SCRAMBLED,
	GENDER AS GENDER,
	CITY AS CITY,
	SALARY,
	CREDIT_CARD
FROM DEMO.V_SALARY);

1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere

You can now import the view to create a Datasphere local table: start the process to create a dummy Datasphere view, select the Sources tab in the source browser, then click on the schema name and Drag and Drop of the View name to the text area. This triggers the table import, click on Import an Deploy, then close the New SQL View object (no need to save it, click on Discard):

Now, the view "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE".V_SALARY_SCRAMBLED can be opened and used in Datasphere:

 

1.3 - Data anonymization

The SAP HANA Data Anonymization Guide explains how to anonymize data. In this blog, we will not focus on the technique used to anonymize data, but rather on sample syntax used to anonymize data. The following SQL code creates a view with the anonymized SALARY column (the view with anonymization will be effective after the REFRESH command):

CREATE VIEW "V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED" AS
(SELECT 
	"ID",
	"NAME",
	GENDER,
	CITY,
	SALARY AS SALARY_ANONYMIZED,
	CREDIT_CARD
FROM DEMO.V_SALARY)
WITH ANONYMIZATION(
	ALGORITHM 'DIFFERENTIAL_PRIVACY'
	PARAMETERS '{"data_change_strategy": "qualified"}'
	COLUMN "ID" PARAMETERS '{"is_sequence": true}'
	COLUMN "SALARY_ANONYMIZED" PARAMETERS '{"is_sensitive":true, "epsilon":0.1, "sensitivity":2000}'
);
REFRESH VIEW "V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED" ANONYMIZATION;

The V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED view can now be imported into Datasphere (see 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere)

2 - Standardization

We've seen above that Open SQL Schema is powerful to create features not implemented in the Datasphere UI but accessible using SQL.

The standardization will allow the SAP Datasphere users to easily activate/deactivate masking, scrambling and anonymization for columns.
A Datasphere local table (VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS) will contain the views definitions and a custom SQL procedure (EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR) will read its content to create the views based on the stored definitions. Then a Task Chain will be created to call the procedure from Datasphere.

2.1 - Parameters table

The table "VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS" will have the following columns:
  • "TARGET_VIEW": name of the view that will be created in the Open SQL Schema
  • "CONFIGURATION": characteristic of the target view. Contains the field name of the unmasked, scrambled anonymized field
  • "SEQ": optional sequence number used to order the list of the view fields
  • "VALUE": value related to the "CONFIGURATION". When "CONFIGURATION" is a field name, it contains an expression (or NULL when the field doesn't need to be changed in the target view) 
  • "CREATE": 'YES' when the target field needs to be created in the target table
  • "RENAME_TO": target field name when "CONFIGURATION" field name needs to be changed
  • "ACTIVATE": 'YES' when the target field "VALUE" needs to be used (when it doesn't start with the keyword 'PARAMETERS'). Otherwise the field name stored in "CONFIGURATION" is used.
CONFIGURATION contains one of the following keywords:
  • '#EXECUTE#': define the behavior of the procedure that will create the target view. When "VALUE" contains the value:
    • 'YES': it creates in the "TARGET_VIEW" view the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES'
    • 'ALL': it ignores the value of the "ACTIVATE" field ; all the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES' will be created with the expression stored in "CONFIGURATION"
    • 'RESET': if ignore the value of the "ACTIVATE" field ; all the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES' will be created with their original definition stored in "VALUE"
  • '#SOURCE_NAME#': when used, then "VALUE" contains the name of the table/view used to create the target view
  • '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#': when used, then VALUE contains the expression used for anonymization (see SAP HANA Data Anonymization Guide)

 

TARGET_VIEWCONFIGURATIONSEQVALUECREATERENAME_TOACTIVATE
V_SALARY_DERIVED#EXECUTE# ALL   
V_SALARY_DERIVED#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE# WITH ANONYMIZATION (ALGORITHM 'DIFFERENTIAL_PRIVACY' PARAMETERS '{"data_change_strategy": "qualified"}'   
V_SALARY_DERIVED#SOURCE_NAME# V_SALARY   
V_SALARY_DERIVEDID1PARAMETERS '{"is_sequence": true}'YES YES
V_SALARY_DERIVEDNAME2INITCAP(SCRAMBLE_STRING(NAME))YESNAME_SCRAMBLEDYES
V_SALARY_DERIVEDGENDER3MAP(GENDER,'M','Mr','F','Ms','')YES  
V_SALARY_DERIVEDCITY4CITY  YES
V_SALARY_DERIVEDSALARY5PARAMETERS '{"is_sensitive":true, "epsilon":0.1, "sensitivity":2000}'YESSALARY_ANONYMIZEDYES
V_SALARY_DERIVEDCREDIT_CARD6LEFT(CREDIT_CARD,4) || '-XXXX-XXXX-' || RIGHT(CREDIT_CARD,4)YESCREDIT_CARD_MASKEDYES

In the previous screenshot, the view V_SALARY_DERIVED will have the following fields and properties:

  • "ID" will remain unchanged
  • "NAME" will be scrambled and renamed to "NAME_SCRAMBLED"
  • "GENDER" will appear not changed in the target view
  • "CITY" will not appear in the target view
  • "SALARY" will be anonymized and renamed to "SALARY_ANONYMIZED"
  • "CREDIT_CARD" will be masked and renamed to "CREDIT_CARD_MASKED"

In order to execute the expressions to create the target columns, a line with '#EXECUTE#' was created.
Since the view contains anonymized data, a line with '#ANONYZATION_TYPE#' was s created.

In order to be able to use this table content into an Open SQL Schema, an SQL view in SAP Datasphere needs to be created : V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS. This view will contain all the fields from the table.

 

2.2 - SQL Procedures

Three SQL procedures are created:

  • EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT: generates a create view statement 
  • EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR: with a string parameter used to filter the view V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS to create only one target view by calling the procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT and embedding the code with instructions to drop the view if it already exists and generates the REFRESH statement if anonymization is used.
  • EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR: calls EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR for the distinct values of TARGET_VEWS.

2.2.1 - Procedure  EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT

This procedure returns the CREATE VIEW statement for one target view defined in the view "VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS" .

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT (
	IN TARGET_NAME_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN CURRENT_SPACE_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN CURRENT_SCHEMA_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN EXECUTE_ VARCHAR(1000),
	OUT FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ INTEGER,
	OUT SQL_DDL VARCHAR (2500)
)
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE PART1 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART2 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART3 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART4 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART5 VARCHAR(2500);

	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 1: begining part to create the target view
	*/
    SELECT TOP 1 'CREATE VIEW '||:CURRENT_SCHEMA_||'.'|| :TARGET_NAME_ AS x
    into PART1 
    FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
    WHERE "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 2: list columns for the target view
	*/
	WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			"CONFIGURATION" AS "CONFIGURATION",
			"SEQ" AS "SEQ",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE",
			"CREATE" AS "CREATE",
			"RENAME_TO" AS "RENAME_TO"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_
		)
    SELECT ' ( ' ||
	    string_agg( IFNULL(RENAME_TO,"CONFIGURATION" )
	    	    , ', ' ORDER BY "SEQ" ) ||
	    ' ) as select ' ||
	    string_agg( 
	        IFNULL(
	            ( CASE WHEN "VALUE" LIKE 'PARAMETERS%' 
					THEN NULL 
					ELSE "VALUE" 
	            END ) 
	            , "CONFIGURATION"
	        ) ||
			' as ' ||
			IFNULL( RENAME_TO, "CONFIGURATION" )
			, ', ' ORDER BY "SEQ"
		) 
    AS x 
    INTO PART2
    FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
    WHERE "CREATE" = 'YES';
    
	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 3: select expression for the target view
	*/
	SELECT TOP 1 ' from '|| :CURRENT_SPACE_ || '.' || "VALUE" 
	as x 
	into PART3 
	FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
	WHERE "CONFIGURATION" = '#SOURCE_NAME#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

	WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND "CREATE"='YES'
			AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 
						FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
						WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND :EXECUTE_ in ('YES','ALL')
						)
		)
	SELECT count(*) as x
	INTO FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_
	FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
	WHERE "VALUE" LIKE 'PARAMETERS%' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
	
	IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN
		/*
		CREATE VIEW PART 4: add predicate for anonymization
		*/
	    SELECT "VALUE" AS x 
	    INTO PART4 
	    FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
	    WHERE "CONFIGURATION" = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
	
		/*
		CREATE VIEW PART 5: list parameters for anonymization
		*/
		WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			"CONFIGURATION" AS "CONFIGURATION",
			"SEQ" AS "SEQ",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE",
			"RENAME_TO" as "RENAME_TO"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND "CREATE"='YES'
			AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 
						FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
						WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND :EXECUTE_ in ('YES','ALL')
						)
		)
		SELECT string_agg('Column ' || IFNULL(RENAME_TO,"CONFIGURATION") || ' ' || "VALUE", ' ' ORDER BY "SEQ") ||' )' AS x
	    INTO PART5
	    FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
	    WHERE UPPER(LEFT("VALUE",10))='PARAMETERS' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
		
	END IF;	   
	
    select string_agg(x, ' ' order by rn) as x 
    into SQL_DDL from (
	    SELECT :PART1 as x ,1 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART2 as x ,2 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART3 as x ,3 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART4 as x ,4 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL    
	    SELECT :PART5 as x ,5 as rn from DUMMY
    ) a ;
END

 

2.2.2 - Procedure  EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR

This procedure creates the SQL instructions to create one target view.

It contains:

  • a DROP command that will be executed if the TARGET_VIEW is already existing
  • a CREATE VIEW command to create the TARGET_VIEW
  • A REFRESH command if TARGET_VIEW contains any field that needs to be anonymized

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR (IN TARGET_NAME_ VARCHAR (1000)) 
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE SQL_DROP VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE SQL_DDL VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE EXECUTE_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE REFRESH_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE FLAG_DROP_ INTEGER;
    DECLARE FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ INTEGER;
    DECLARE CURRENT_SCHEMA_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE CURRENT_SPACE_ VARCHAR(2500);

SELECT UPPER("VALUE") as x into EXECUTE_ FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#EXECUTE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

IF :EXECUTE_ IN ('YES', 'RESET', 'ALL') THEN
	SELECT 'DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE' into CURRENT_SCHEMA_ FROM DUMMY;
	SELECT SUBSTR_BEFORE(:CURRENT_SCHEMA_, '#') into CURRENT_SPACE_ from DUMMY;
    SELECT count (*) INTO FLAG_DROP_ FROM views WHERE schema_name=:CURRENT_SCHEMA_ and view_name=:TARGET_NAME_;
   
    /*
    DROP SQL expression to premare the replacement for the target view.
    */
    SELECT TOP 1 'DROP VIEW '||:CURRENT_SCHEMA_||'.'||:TARGET_NAME_ ||' ; ' as x 
    into SQL_DROP
    from DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS WHERE "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

    /*
    CREATE SQL expression to create the target view.
    */
	CALL "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE"."EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT"(
		TARGET_NAME_ => :TARGET_NAME_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		CURRENT_SPACE_ => :CURRENT_SPACE_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		CURRENT_SCHEMA_ => :CURRENT_SCHEMA_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		EXECUTE_ => :EXECUTE_/*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ => FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_,
		SQL_DDL => SQL_DDL
	);
	
	IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN    
	    /*
	    REFRESH SQL expression for anonymization feature.
	    */
	    SELECT 'REFRESH VIEW '|| :CURRENT_SCHEMA_ ||'.'|| :TARGET_NAME_ || ' ANONYMIZATION;'
	    INTO REFRESH_ 
	    FROM DUMMY ;
	END IF;

    IF FLAG_DROP_ <> 0 THEN 
        EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SQL_DROP;
    END IF;

    EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SQL_DDL;
    IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN
    	EXECUTE IMMEDIATE REFRESH_;
    END IF;

END IF;
END

2.2.3 - Procedure  EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR

This procedure calls the procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR for all the distinct values for TARGET_VIEW.

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR()
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
	DECLARE CURSOR c_cursor FOR SELECT DISTINCT TARGET_VIEW FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS;
	FOR rec as c_cursor
	DO
	    CALL "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE"."EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR" (:rec.TARGET_VIEW);
  END FOR;
END

2.3 - Task Chain

In order to be autonomous to mask, scramble and anonymize data in Datasphere (without accessing to the Open SQL Schema) a task chain can be created to call the SQL procedure EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR.

2.3.1 - Grant permissions

Datasphere space needs to view and run the SQL Procedure that was created in the Open SQL Schema, some grants need to be done in SQL Developer by  the user DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE to the Datasphere space user.

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
 
CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" (
	OPERATION => 'GRANT', 
	PRIVILEGE => 'EXECUTE', 
	SCHEMA_NAME => 'DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE', 
	OBJECT_NAME => '', 
	SPACE_ID => 'DEMO');

2.3.2 - Create a task chain

 

2.3.3 - Test

For testing purposes, we can use the parameters table described in 2.1 - Parameters table .

After running the task chain, the view V_SALARY_DERIVED was created and can now be imported into the Datasphere space (see 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere ).

Finally your space should contain this list of objects: 

 

If you open V_SALARY_DERIVED:

 

Conclusion

If you face some missing features in Datasphere, consider Open SQL Schema, it may offer you the opportunity to implement what you miss using the underlying SAP HANA Cloud database.

If you liked this blog, say it by clicking on the Like button.

entry.title: Rewiring of SAP Datasphere to SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
The rewiring of existing SAP Datasphere tenants to SAP Business Data Cloud has become available in 2025. Since then, I have been in many discussions with customers, partners, but also SAP colleagues at SAP TechEd in Berlin, Sydney and other events or meetings.

I observed that people unintentionally misinterpret the term ‚Äúrewiring‚Äù. It sounds technical, hence there are associations with data, object or even full tenant migrations. This is not the case!

Let me use this blog to clarify what rewiring is, and what it is not. Moreover, give you some guidance on the steps which you need to take.

 

‚ÄÉ

When do I need to rewire my existing SAP Datasphere tenant?

You have made a decision to sign up for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and to make use of your existing tenants for SAP Datasphere and / or SAP Analytics Cloud as part of your new landscape with SAP BDC.

If you have not made any decision on SAP BDC yet, you can certainly use your existing tenant(s) until the end of your current contract without SAP BDC. However, you will miss out on new capabilities offered by SAP BDC with SAP managed data products and the enhanced open partner ecosystem options.

 

What is tenant rewiring?

The term ‚Äúrewiring‚Äù sounds quite technical. Therefore, there are immediate associations with data, object or even full tenant migrations. This is not the case!

  1. The term rewiring mainly refers to a change of your commercial model from a stand-alone tenant to a tenant which is managed as part of a larger SAP BDC landscape.
  2. Rewiring helps you change the management of your tenant lifecycle to the SAP for Me portal.
  3. Prerequisites are that you commercially move the tenant on your same customer ID and your current data center being available also for Business Data Cloud. Please check on these two points!
  4. If these conditions are met a lot will stay the same. Meaning you stay on your existing hyperscaler and data center. Hence, your tenant and its URL will remain intact, just under a new commercial model, even without any downtime required.

 

What is tenant rewiring not?

Rewiring is therefore not a tenant migration as your existing tenant stays the same and is reused as part of an SAP BDC landscape.

Rewiring does not migrate your tenant between hyperscalers or data centers, as with the conditions mentioned before, your current data center ‚Äì given that it is available for SAP BDC ‚Äì will stay the same on your existing customer ID.

Rewiring does not migrate your data or any objects, as the full existing tenant is only commercially moved as described before.

Rewiring does not require any tenant downtime.

 

How can I initiate a tenant rewiring?

Before you can start to initiate the rewiring, you need to change the commercial model of your SAP Datasphere tenant to a Business Data Cloud contract ‚Äì in short: a subscription to SAP Business Data Cloud must exist.

For tenants provisioned via BTP cockpit

After the commercial change, your SAP BTP administrator can initiate the tenant rewiring directly through the SAP BTP platform global account as a self-service. You control the timing of rewiring yourself, as you can trigger it via self-service.

Once the request is received, the process is initiated to update the tenant and move it to SAP Business Data Cloud. The tenant will be visible in SAP Business Data Cloud when the rewiring is completed.

For subscription tenants provisioned by SAP

After the commercial change, your subscription is moved from standalone to SAP Business Data Cloud. Be aware, that the SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit feature must be activated in your appropriate data center through SAP for Me portal prior to rewiring.

The rewiring itself is initiated as part of the subscription change request. That means, your tenant is automatically moved to SAP Business Data Cloud for the contract start date.

 

Where do I find more detailed information?

For more details I recommend these three resources:

SAP Community Blog by @Ammar_Naji:
üîó UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Help documentation for detailed steps:
üîó  Rewiring of Standalone SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Subscriptions to SAP Business Data Cloud

üîó  SAP Note 3650483

 

Let me know if there are still questions about rewiring and post them below üëá in the comments section. I will try to answer them and loop in colleagues in case I do not know the answer myself.

entry.title: Connecting SAP Analytics Cloud to Databricks model serving endpoint
entry.content:
Scenario

Imagine your data scientists have worked their magic and built a predictive (I should call it AI now) model that you wish to access from an SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) story. The model may require parameters to analyze specific data, or you may require the latest output to be retrieved

This can be achieved using the SAC Multi Action feature. Databricks and SAC both support OAuth 2.0 for authentication. A service principal is used for authorization and authentication outside of the standard Databricks UI. The SAC Multi Action feature offers different actions(steps), including an API step which utilises a secure HTTP API connection

Prerequisites

Required Solutions

SAP Analytics Cloud
Databricks

Required users access

SAP Analytics Cloud BI Admin or SAP Analytic Cloud Planning
Databricks Workspace Admin

Required artefacts

Databricks Model Serving Endpoint

OAuth with Databricks / SAP Databricks

The steps are the same with native Databricks and SAP Databricks. The Databricks documentation describes the generic steps and required parameters for OAuth 2.0 authorization. 
https://docs.databricks.com/aws/en/dev-tools/auth/oauth-u2m 
The SAC HTTP API connection requires 5 parameters from Databricks.

  • Data Service URL
  • OAuth Client ID
  • Secret
  • Token URL
  • Scope

Databricks Service Principal

We must first create service principal in Databricks, this can be at either the account or the workspace level. 
Here I have created the service principal within the workspace.

Navigate to User Settings -> Identity and Access

Identity and Access

Add Service Principal

Add Service Principal

 

Add Service Principal Continued

Add Service Principal Name

OAuth Secret

With the Service Principal created we can generate the secret required for authentication

Service Principal

Service Principal Secrets

Service Principal Generate OAuth Secret

Generate OAuth Secret - Lifetime

We need the secret and client details for the SAC connection, copy them somewhere safe

Generate Secret

Serving Endpoint Permissions

The service principal requires execute/query permission on the model serving end point.
We can add the permission via code or the UI as below

Model Serving Endpoint

Model Serving Endpoint Details

Model Serving Endpoint Permissions

SAP Analytics Cloud Connection

Switch to SAC, we need to define a new HTTP API connection

SAP Analytics Cloud HTTP API ConnectionSAP Analytics Cloud HTTP API Connection DialogueSAP Analytics Cloud HTTP API Connection with Placeholders

When we click "Create" it validates the connection details.

SAC Multi Action

Define a new SAC Multi Action using the connection defined.

SAP Analytics Cloud New Multi ActionMulti Action - Add API StepMulti Action API Step

Within the Multi Action properties we can select the previously defined connection. 
The API Request URL is required again here, we can paste in the Model Serving Endpoint here.

SAP Analytics Cloud Story

The multi action defined above needs to be included within an SAC story

SAC Story Add Multi Action Starter ComponentSAC Multi Action Starter Properties

We can test the Multi Action call by clicking on the play button. 

SAC Execute Multi ActionSAC Multi Action Complete

All being well, once completed we can see an additional notification available

SAC Multi Action Notifications

SAP Analytics Cloud Job Monitor

The Multi Action history is captured within the Job Monitor

SAP Analytics Cloud - System Job MonitorJob Monitor History

Conclusion

In this blogpost I have shown that integrating a Databricks model serving endpoint can be achieved with only a few steps using out of the box features from Databricks and SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: C_PURCHASEORDERITEMDEX - Add the creation date field of the purchase order item
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I recently raised a case with SAP regarding the standard CDS View for purchase order items, C_PURCHASEORDERITEMDEX, which currently returns the header creation date for all items. After reviewing the case, the SAP support team confirmed that this is the expected behavior and suggested submitting an idea on their Influence platform. My ERP is S/4HANA Public Cloud.

The goal of this blog post is to gather support from the community so that this improvement can be prioritized. If you agree that having the correct item-level creation date would add value, please take a moment to vote for my idea on the SAP Influence website. Your vote can make a real difference!

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/362226

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,

Miquel

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in December
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in December

What a year it has been. Wow! 2025 was packed with great events, lots of new features and enhancements to extend existing features, and the launch of SAP Business Data Cloud. 
Explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and enjoy watching my top feature highlights for 2025 on YouTube üì∫ below.

 

SAP Datasphere 2025 highlights in a nutshell

What a great ride it has been in 2025 with SAP Datasphere!
Let me share a few of my personal highlights.

SAP Business Data Cloud

The announcement of SAP Business Data Cloud in February this year made quite some noise and puts data, analytics and AI at the center of our portfolio at SAP. We delivered SAP Business Data Cloud in May 2025 as a fully managed software as a service solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data.

It is an evolution of the business data fabric journey we started with SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud some years ago and also offers a path forward for your investments in SAP BW.

Delivering out-of-the-box always-on data products is the next pivotal step in our data strategy following a harmonized data model to provide scalable access without duplication using zero-copy delta share technology.

SAP BDC serves as the foundation for your data and AI projects leveraging SAP managed and custom data products, including our growing open partner ecosystem with Databricks and the newly announced partnerships with Google Big Query, Snowflake and Microsoft Fabric.

 

My top features in 2025

Picking my top features for all of 2025 was not easy and here is my top feature list in no particular order.

 

Object store (general availability)

In 2025 we delivered the option to include an object store next to the well-known SAP HANA Cloud based persistency for a cost-efficient storage. You can use the existing tooling you already know to now create local tables on files, use replication flows, transformation flows which are then using Spark as compute engine - all orchestrated by task chains. You can load large quantities of data via replication flows and prepare the data using transformation flows and then share data to other spaces to be used as a source for additional flows, views, and of course analytic models. A really great enhancement!

 

Versioning of data builder objects

Object versioning has been introduced for views, analytic models, data access controls, and local tables. The new object versions are created automatically at the time of deployment which allows you now to list the past versions of objects, open a past version in read-only mode in a new tab, download a past version to a CSN/JSON file and restore a past version to replace the current version.

Be aware that the saving of an error-free restored version overwrites the current object. It is also important to understand that the versioning happens for the metadata of an object and not the data.

 

Efficiency features

Then there are tons of smaller enhancements that have been delivered in 2025 to increase efficiency and productivity overall. Let me just name a few here for the different components of Datasphere.

Analytic model

  •  stacking and reusing of models
  •  support for structures and data access controls for analytic models
  •  we introduced a measure-dependency graph, the fiscal time dimension and unit conversion
  •  and many enhancements with variables and parameters

Replication flows

  • delta only load type
  • support for views
  • reusing of source objects in multiple flows
  • many new sources and targets

Transformation flows

  • batch processing
  • parameter support
  • HANA tables as source in Spark transformation flows
  • other features bringing Spark transformation flows almost on par with HANA Cloud based ones

Task chains

  • deep retry of failed tasks in nested task chains
  • Rest API
  • Parameter support
  • notification tasks
  • amongst other improvements

Catalog

  • Support for SAP BW/4HANA, seamless planning, SAP BDC data products, Databricks via BDC connect
  • GenAI-assisted generation of catalog asset descriptions and classifications
  • Mass import of existing glossaries, terms, KPI‚Äôs, etc. from flat files

 

SAP Cloud application lifecycle management

SAP Datasphere is now integrated into SAP Cloud application lifecycle management (ALM) for health, job and automation monitoring.

Health monitoring enables you to check the health of one or more Datasphere tenants from the Health Monitoring app in Cloud ALM to check on 

  • Memory and Disk usage
  • Out of Memory Events
  • Task Failures and
  • Admission Control Events

Job and automation monitoring enables you to monitor the tasks runs and executions in one or more SAP Datasphere tenants from the Job and Automation Monitoring app in Cloud ALM.

The integration overall eases the monitoring of an SAP Datasphere tenant in a complex customer landscape with a centralized, consistent way of tracking the tenants.

In addition, the early watch alert reports are now also available for SAP Datasphere. EWA is an automatic service analyzing the essential administrative areas of your SAP systems and covered by your maintenance agreement.

 

Data access controls based on IdP attributes

Data access controls based on identity provider (IdP) attributes are a small enhancement, but it is very powerful. You can now use values in custom attributes provided by your IdP as identifiers in your data access controls and define conditions that apply to users with these values. It is powerful because using these attributes allows you to apply a single condition to all users whose accounts contain that specific attribute value. In other words, you can group users with attributes to assign permissions to a group instead of individual users.

 

YouTube feature highlights of 2025

 

 

 

And more feature highlights of 2025

There are so many more great features which we delivered in 2025, so in addition to my 2025 top features, I pulled together the 2025 feature highlights in all different areas of SAP Datasphere for you. Enjoy the ride!

Data Integration

‚ÄÉ

 

Catalog & Monitoring

 

Data Modelling

 

Miscellaneous

 

What exactly is rewiring for SAP Datasphere?

I have heard that question so many times over the last few months from customers, partners, but also SAP colleagues at events like SAP TechEd in Berlin or Sydney. 
During these discussions I observed that people unintentionally misinterpret the term ‚Äúrewiring‚Äù. It sounds technical, hence there are associations with data, object or even full tenant migrations. This is not the case!

Therefore, I wrote a blog to clarify what rewiring is, and what it is not. Moreover, give you some guidance on the steps which you need to take.
