entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Certification (C_BCBDC): The Ultimate Guide to Passing SAP‚Äôs New AI Scenario
entry.content:
Introduction

Certification is changing, and it is a good thing. Instead of cramming facts and guessing at multiple choice, you are invited to think like you do on the job. You will work through real scenarios, connect the dots, and show how you deliver outcomes. In this post we will talk about what is new, and how to prepare for SAP BDC (C_BCBDC) certification.

Understanding the New BDC Certification Format - Scenario Based

You will interact with an AI avatar to respond to real customer or project situations. For learners who prefer not to use AI there is an alternative option to upload a video for human review. Link for more details : SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format, Reimagining Certification

Preparation

SAP BDC Learning Journey

For the best chance of success, complete the full SAP Business Data Cloud learning journey from start to finish. Treat every module, hands on exercise, and quiz as required to build real exam readiness. Give special attention to the core topics below

Core Topics in SAP Business Data Cloud

1. BDC

  • One domain model
  • SAP 4 Me
  • Formations
  • Intelligent Applications
  • Data Products
  • Data Security
  • Architecture
  • BDC Cockpit
  • Zero copy
  • ORD / CSN
  • Data Lake

2. SAP Datasphere Integration

  • BDC-generated spaces
  • Harmonization through modeling
  • Semantic enrichment
  • Extending SAP-delivered models
  • Installing data products to a space

3. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Role of SAC in BDC
  • Extending and discovering intelligent applications
  • Use cases for intelligent applications

4. BW Modernization

  • Lift, shift, and innovate strategies
  • Data Product Generator
  • Subscriptions and versions
  • Why BW is included in BDC

5. SAP Databricks Integration

  • ML Flow, delta share, notebooks, Unity Catalog
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Industry use cases
  • Sharing data products and ML results between Databricks and BDC

Sample Scenarios to Understand the Exam Format

Scenario 1: Global Manufacturing Company ‚Äì Unified Analytics & Governance

Context: A global manufacturing company operates across Europe and Asia. They run SAP S/4HANA, legacy SAP BW, and several non-SAP systems for logistics and procurement. Leadership wants a single, governed analytics platform with reusable data products and ready-made insights.

Question: How does BDC help

Scenario 2: Financial Services Firm ‚Äì AI-Driven Risk & Compliance Reporting

Context: A financial services firm needs real-time risk reporting, strict compliance, and AI-driven forecasting. They must integrate SAP finance data with external market feeds and apply advanced analytics.

Question: How can Financial Services Firm integrate third-party data with its SAP data using SAP Business Data Cloud?

Exam Questions Breakdown from My Attempt

Based on my recent experience, here‚Äôs how the exam questions were distributed:

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC: 40%
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks: 15%

Helpful Links

  1. Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey
  2. SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format
  3. Reimagining Certification
  4. SAP Certified Associate SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Working with BW Authorizations in Datasphere on Enterprise Level
entry.content:
Related resources

  • Blog Post: Introducing Remote Authorizations from SAP BW/4HANA for SAP Datasphere 
  • Blog Post by @Martin_Kuma: BW-Like Authorizations in Datasphere (DSP) 
  • Documentation: Import SAP BW and SAP BW‚àï4HANA Analysis Authorizations 
  • Note: 3062381

 

Why resolve BW authorizations in Datasphere?

In enterprise analytics SAP Datasphere often needs to federates the SAP BW analysis authorization table RSDWC_RSEC_DAC to data access controls (DAC). We build on this SAP standard (no custom BW developments are required beyond generation/extraction of the standard table) and bring the resolution step into the HANA layer for scale and performance.

Performance matters: The default runtime-only resolution evaluates long WHERE predicate strings per session user and iterates them at query time. With many users and complex rules, that becomes inperformant and unpredictable in terms of latency. By pre‚Äëresolving per objectinto a persisted table we decouple expensive checks from BI queries, achieve consistent, auditable results, and enable scheduled refreshes.

 

Prerequisites

  1. RSDWC_RSEC_DAC as a Remote Table in Datasphere. Generate/refresh it in BW with transaction RSDWC_DAC_RSEC_GEN and the BAdI RSDWC_DAC_RSEC_USER_UPDATE (and optionally schedule report RSDWC_DAC_RSEC_EXTRACT). The table can then be exposed to Datasphere. 
  2. A HANA DB user (Open SQL schema) in Datasphere. This user owns the Function, Procedure and Table and is granted to the space technical user to run in Task Chains.
  3. Optional: an Entities/"booked values" table/view. Applying predicates to the set of actually booked combinations avoids generating all possible cross‚Äëcombinations which can be a huge performance multiplier and inflate result sizes.

 

Where our default approaches falls short

  • Runtime resolution per current user leads to high CPU/time due to long predicate strings.
  • SQL views in Datasphere lack loops/cursors; scaling to many users is cumbersome.
  • Duplicating views per user and UNION them is not maintainable and limits parallelization.

 

Example at a glance

In this blog‚Äôs walkthrough OBJECT01 is our authorization object that groups the key BW characteristics used for data access in the BWAUTH02 mapping. Concretely, OBJECT01 controls combinations of the following standard InfoObjects:

  • /BIC/0COMP_CODE (Company Code)
  • /BIC/0PLANT (Plant)
  • /BIC/0SALESORG (Sales Organization)
  • /BIC/0PROFIT_CTR (Profit Center)
  • /BIC/0CS_PLEVEL

The SAP standard table RSDWC_RSEC_DAC (federated as a remote table to Datasphere) holds per BW user and per object the dynamic WHERE‚Äëpredicate string that expresses allowed values/ranges for these characteristics.

 

Solution overview: Function + Procedure + Table + Task Chain + View

We implement five building blocks in an Open SQL schema and orchestrate them from Datasphere:

  1. Table Function `TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02`: reads normalized WHERE predicate from RSEC view and applies it to booked entities via `APPLY_FILTER`.
  2. Procedure `SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02`: loops over all BW users for OBJECT01 and persists the union of results into a target table (full refresh).
  3. Persisted table `AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02`: mirrors function output for /BIC/0* fields.
  4. View `GV_AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02`: exposes the table for DACs and downstream pipelines.
  5. Task Chain `TC_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02`: schedules the refresh procedure regularly.

Source artifacts and naming

  • RSEC (clean) view: "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02" (column FILTERFIELDNM holds the normalized predicate)
  • Entities view (booked combinations): "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_OBJECT01_DAC_ENTITIES_BOOKED_BWAUTH02"
  • Target table: "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02"
  • Exposing view: "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02"
  • Task Chain: TC_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02

Target table 

CREATE COLUMN TABLE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02" (
    "User"             NVARCHAR(256),
    "OBJECTNAME"       NVARCHAR(40),
    "/BIC/0PLANT"      NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0SALESORG"   NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL"  NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"  NVARCHAR(20)
);

Table Function 

/* --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Object:   FUNCTION "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"
   Purpose:  For a given BW user, returns the authorized ENTITY combinations
             for OBJECT01 (fixed here; can be parameterized later).
             The WHERE predicate string is read dynamically from the RSEC view
             and applied to the Entities view via APPLY_FILTER.

   Input:    P_USER (NVARCHAR(256)) ‚Äì BWUSERID for which the authorization resolution is executed.

   Output:   Result set with the following columns (aligned to the new standard InfoObjects):
             "User", "OBJECTNAME",
             "/BIC/0PLANT", "/BIC/0SALESORG", "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
             "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR", "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"

   Assumptions & behavior:
     - Exactly ONE record exists in the RSEC view for (BWUSERID = P_USER, OBJECTNAME = 'OBJECT01_BWAUTH02').
       -> SELECT ... INTO expects exactly 1 row. More than one -> "row not unique"; none -> "no data found".
     - INFOOBJ is intentionally fixed to 'OBJECT01_BWAUTH02' for this scenario.
     - APPLY_FILTER expects a syntactically valid WHERE string (without the "WHERE" keyword).

   Security/runtime:
     - SQL SECURITY INVOKER: Privilege checks are executed in the caller's context.
       -> Caller must have SELECT on the views used in the space/schema.
     - APPLY_FILTER is safer than EXEC/EXECUTE IMMEDIATE regarding SQL injection,
       however FILTERFIELDNM must be maintained reliably in the RSEC view.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
CREATE FUNCTION "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"(
    IN P_USER NVARCHAR(256)
)
RETURNS TABLE (
    "User"           NVARCHAR(256),
    "OBJECTNAME"     NVARCHAR(40),
    "/BIC/0PLANT"    NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0SALESORG" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"  NVARCHAR(20)
)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY INVOKER
AS
BEGIN
    /* Local variables:
       - FILTER_CLAUSE: holds the dynamic WHERE predicate read from the RSEC view
       - INFOOBJ: fixed to OBJECT01 (current scenario)
    */
    DECLARE FILTER_CLAUSE NCLOB;
    DECLARE INFOOBJ NVARCHAR(40);

    /* Fixed authorization object; can be modeled as IN parameter if needed */
    INFOOBJ = 'OBJECT01';

    /* 1) Load filter string for the user.
          Expects exactly one match. If SELECT returns 0 or >1 rows, HANA raises an exception.
          This should be ensured in the RSEC view content. */
    SELECT FILTERFIELDNM
      INTO FILTER_CLAUSE
      FROM "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02"
     WHERE BWUSERID   = :P_USER
       AND OBJECTNAME = INFOOBJ;

    /* 2) APPLY_FILTER:
          - Applies the dynamic WHERE expression to the entities view.
          - The result is materialized in the implicit table variable lt_result. */
    lt_result = APPLY_FILTER(
        "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_OBJECT01_DAC_ENTITIES_BOOKED_BWAUTH02",
        :FILTER_CLAUSE
    );

    /* 3) Assemble result:
          - DISTINCT -> avoid duplicates.
          - P_USER and INFOOBJ are carried as constant columns. */
    RETURN
    SELECT DISTINCT
        :P_USER    AS "User",
        INFOOBJ    AS "OBJECTNAME",
        "/BIC/0PLANT",
        "/BIC/0SALESORG",
        "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
        "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR",
        "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"
    FROM :lt_result;
END;

You can check how it is working: 

SELECT * FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"('ABC02')

Procedure

/* --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Object:   PROCEDURE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02"
   Purpose:  Full-refresh build of table "AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02":
             - Collect all BWUSERID relevant for OBJECT01 (from GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02)
             - For each user, call table function TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02
             - Persist the union of results into the target table

   Flow:
     1) Cursor over DISTINCT BWUSERID from the RSEC view (OBJECTNAME = 'OBJECT01')
     2) DELETE the target table (clear all rows for a full rebuild)
     3) FOR-loop: INSERT ... SELECT from the table function for each user

   Security:
     - SQL SECURITY INVOKER: privilege checks run in caller context
     - Caller requires:
       * SELECT on source RSEC view
       * INSERT/DELETE on target table

   Performance:
     - Loop calls the TF once per user (N calls).
       For large N, consider a set-based approach (bulk table function) later.

   Notes:
     - INSERT lists columns explicitly to guard against future schema changes
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
CREATE PROCEDURE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02" ()
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY INVOKER
AS
BEGIN

  /* 1) Cursor: distinct list of relevant users for OBJECT01 */
  DECLARE CURSOR cur_users FOR
    SELECT DISTINCT BWUSERID
      FROM "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02"
     WHERE OBJECTNAME = 'OBJECT01'
       AND BWUSERID   IS NOT NULL;

  /* 2) Full rebuild: clear target table */
  DELETE FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02";

  /* 3) Implicit FOR-loop: HANA opens/closes the cursor automatically */
  FOR cur_row AS cur_users DO

    INSERT INTO "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02"
      ( "User", "OBJECTNAME",
        "/BIC/0PLANT", "/BIC/0SALESORG", "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
        "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR", "/BIC/0COMP_CODE" )
    SELECT
        "User", "OBJECTNAME",
        "/BIC/0PLANT", "/BIC/0SALESORG", "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
        "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR", "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"
    FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"( :cur_row.BWUSERID );

  END FOR;

END;

Execute via Task Chain step or manually:

CALL "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02"();
SELECT * FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02";

Security, view exposure, and task chain

  • Create Datasphere view: "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02" over the table to feed DACs and downstream processes. 

  • Schedule a Task Chain "TC_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02" that calls the procedure for regular refresh.

To add the procedure your user needs to be granted: 

-- Minimal grants (adapt to your technical user / space)
GRANT EXECUTE ON PROCEDURE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02" TO "DEMO_AR_001";
GRANT SELECT, INSERT, DELETE ON "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02" TO "DEMO_AR_001";
-- Optional: schema-wide
GRANT EXECUTE ON SCHEMA "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01" TO "DEMO_AR_001" WITH GRANT OPTION;

If you do not know the needed Schema: 

SELECT SCHEMA_NAME, SCHEMA_OWNER
FROM SYS.SCHEMAS

 

Performance & scalability

  • Pre-resolving moves string evaluation out of query-time; persisted results enable indexes and faster joins.
  • Keep the entities view "booked" to avoid generating all combinations (Cartesian blow-up).
  • For very large user counts, consider a set-based bulk table function to avoid N function calls.

 

Troubleshooting

  • Error 260 invalid column name: fix duplicated /BIC/ prefixes or mismatched InfoObject names.
  • No data found / row not unique: enforce exactly 1 row per (BWUSERID, OBJECTNAME) in RSEC view.
  • Permissions: INVOKER needs SELECT on sources and INSERT/DELETE on target; scheduler user needs EXECUTE on procedure.

 

What you get

A maintainable, enterprise-ready pattern to pre-resolve BW authorizations in SAP Datasphere, fully based on SAP standard RSDWC_RSEC_DAC: reproducible results, faster queries and a scheduling hook via Task Chains. From here, you can attach DACs to exposed views or plug the table into harmonization and governance pipelines.

entry.title: Generating and Integrating Automated Predictive Library (APL) Forecasts in a Seamless Planning Model
entry.content:
Introduction 

SAP Analytics Cloud has always been the one solution for BI, planning and predictive analytics. As such, it has powerful built-in capabilities for regression, classification and time-series forecasting. You know them as Predictive Scenarios and many of you have used them to support their planning processes. Our predictive scenarios are perfect for business users: they choose the best available algorithm for your data and explain the results while maintaining the semantics of the model throughout the process (e.g., hierarchies). With SAP Business Data Cloud and seamless planning, data scientists on the other hand can now leverage HANA‚Äôs predictive Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL) directly on the HANA database of SAP Datasphere and nicely integrate the results into planning processes. This lets them tweak predictive models by picking and choosing the algorithm of their choice and use code instead of a UI. SAP BDC would also allow them to share data with SAP Databricks or another Databricks instance using data products if this was their preferred environment. 

This blogpost was created with @marc_daniau, a development expert for our predictive engine. We want to demonstrate the usage of HANA APL in combination with a seamless planning model and live versions. We do this using a straight-forward prediction based on actual data.  

 

High-level overview 

This is what we are working with: 

In SAP Analytics Cloud, we have a planning model deployed to an SAP Datasphere space. That makes it a seamless planning model which means that its data is not stored on the SAP Analytics Cloud database but only on the SAP Datasphere database.  

In the SAP Datasphere space, we find the planning model data and a table with actuals. We are not using an SAP BDC data product, but you surely could! 

We create our prediction directly on the underlying HANA Cloud database of SAP Datasphere. We created a DB user to access the database. There, we consume the actuals, create a stored procedure which we can trigger via a task chain, and surface the result in a view in the space. This fact data can then be added to the seamless planning model as a live version.  

 

Step-by-step 

1. Seamless planning model 

We do not cover the full creation and set-up of the model. Let‚Äôs just check out its key characteristics:  

  • It is a seamless planning model, deployed to the space Sales Planning Demo 
  • Its fact table is exposed in the SAP Datasphere space (actually, this is not decisive for the use case described here but could be useful if you want to add budget data as influence for your predictive model, for instance) 
  •  We want to create a forecast version and predict the measure SALES_REVENUE along the product and region dimension 

2. SAP Datasphere space

Again, we do not look at the creation of the space and all its artefacts. The following Actuals view is key as we extrapolate our forecast based on this data: 

  • Measures and attributes nicely match the planning model structure (which is handy for our simple demo scenario J) 
  • We excluded columns that we do not need in a projection 
  • We filtered on date as we do not want to use the entire history 

3. Setting up database access 

We are now ready to learn how to create the forecast on the HANA database. First of all, we need to set up database access.  

  • Prerequisite: Enable the SAP HANA Cloud Script Server on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant 
  • Navigate to Space Management, find your space and Edit.  
  • Navigate to Database Access and create a new user 
     
  • Name your user and make the needed settings as highlighted. Your user‚Äôs name will be a concatenation of your space name, ‚Äò#‚Äô and the suffix you provide here. 
     
  • Mark your user and open the database explorer. The password can be retrieved in the details of the user (information symbol).  

4. Database explorer 

Let‚Äôs first have an overview of what we are creating in the database explorer: 

 

  • We create a view that consumes the actual data from our space schema. Note the following: 
  • We concatenate Product and Region to one Entity column that we will use to segment our prediction. As we work directly on flat fact tables/views, we do not have the luxury of keeping all semantics as we have it in the SAP Analytics Cloud predictive scenarios.  

 

CREATE VIEW "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_SERIES_IN" ( "Entity", "Date", "SalesRevenue" ) AS (select   
  "Product" || '|' || "Regions" as "Entity", "Date", "SalesRevenue" 
 from  
  SALES_PLANNING_DEMO."V_Actual_Sales_Data" 
 order by 1, 2)

  • We now create the prediction task as a stored procedure.  
create procedure "APL_FORECAST_TASK" 
as BEGIN
    declare header "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.FUNCTION_HEADER";
    declare config "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_CONFIG_DETAILED";
	declare var_desc "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_DESC_OID";   
    declare var_role "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_ROLES_WITH_COMPOSITES_OID";    
    declare apl_log   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_LOG";      
    declare apl_sum   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.SUMMARY";   
    declare apl_indic   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.INDICATORS";   	
    declare apl_metr "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_METRIC_OID";
    declare apl_prop "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_PROPERTY_OID";      

    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_SERIES_OUT";
    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY";
    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_STATUS";
	
    :header.insert(('Oid', 'DSP APL'));
    :header.insert(('LogLevel', '2'));
    :header.insert(('MaxTasks', '4'));  --  PARALLEL TASKS

    :config.insert(('APL/SegmentColumnName', 'Entity',null)); 
    :config.insert(('APL/Horizon', '12',null));
    :config.insert(('APL/TimePointColumnName', 'Date',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ForcePositiveForecast', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/DecomposeInfluencers', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ApplyExtraMode', 'First Forecast with Stable Components and Residues and Error Bars',null));
	
    :var_role.insert(('Date', 'input', null, null, null));
    :var_role.insert(('SalesRevenue', 'target', null, null, null));
		
    "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::FORECAST_AND_DEBRIEF" (
	:header, :config, :var_desc, :var_role, 
	'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER', 'APL_SERIES_IN', 
	'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER', 'APL_SERIES_OUT', apl_log, apl_sum, apl_indic, apl_metr, apl_prop);

    insert into "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY" 
    select "Oid" as "Entity", "MAE", "MAPE"
    from "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::TimeSeries_Performance" (:apl_prop, :apl_metr)
    where "Partition" = 'Validation';
	
	insert into "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_STATUS" 
    select "OID" as "Entity", "VALUE" as "Task Status"
	from :apl_sum 
	where key = 'AplTaskStatus';
END

For our demo scenario we use the default APL forecasting method that automatically tries different hypotheses for trend, cycles and fluctuations, and eventually selects the combination that gives the best accuracy. For a faster processing on many segments, an option is to force the Exponential Smoothing method by adding to the procedure this line of code below: 

:config.insert(('APL/ForecastMethod','ExponentialSmoothing',null));

This is the code to prepare the target tables of the procedure: 

drop table APL_SERIES_OUT;
create table APL_SERIES_OUT (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "Date" 	DATE,
 "SalesRevenue" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Trend" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Cycles" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_lowerlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_upperlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1ExtraPreds" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Fluctuations" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Residues" DOUBLE
);

 

drop table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY;
create table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "MAE" DOUBLE,
 "MAPE" DOUBLE
);

 

drop table APL_FORECAST_STATUS;
create table APL_FORECAST_STATUS (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "Task Status" nvarchar(180)
);
  • You can trigger this procedure manually using the command below: 
call "APL_FORECAST_TASK" ;

However, in the next chapter, we will also create a task chain in SAP Datasphere to trigger it which can be embedded in real workflows.  

  • You see we generate and write data into three different tables: 
  • The prediction result goes into our results table called APL_SERIES_OUT. This is the data that we want for our seamless planning model. The table has the concatenated entity, date and the predicted revenue. It also comes with upper and lower limit predictions (95%) as well as with fluctuations, extra predictions etc.  
     
  • Optionally, we create the table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY to store the MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error MAE (Mean Absolute Error) per entity. You could filter on the entities you are interested in, the best/worst entities etc. or you could get the MSE (Mean Squared Error) or RMSE (Root Mean Absolute Squared Error) as well.  

  • Optionally, we create the table APL_FORECAST_STATUS where we log the prediction status per entity. All our entities were successful.  

 

5. Task chain 

Stored procedures can be executed via task chains. As such, you can execute them from the SAP Datasphere UI, schedule them or trigger them via external API. Check out the task chain documentation to learn more about prerequisites such as required roles. Soon, you should be able to trigger this API via multi actions in SAP Analytics Cloud as well.  

We must allow the execution of the stored procedure via the SAP Datasphere UI including the creation and deletion of data in the database user schema:  

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'INSERT',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

              

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'DELETE',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

 

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'EXECUTE',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

Setting up task chains is simple. To add a stored procedures, you select Others and browse through the available procedures that are available for your space. Then you drag the procedure on to the canvas to add it as a task.    

You can add replication flows, transformation flows, intelligent lookups etc. to your task chains. By that, you could for instance first refresh actuals and get them into shape so you can use them for your prediction. Or, you add an email notification task to receive updates after the execution of the task chain (I did that in the example below).  

6. Consuming results in the SAP Datasphere space 

Now that we have the predictive logic to calculate and we can execute it via the SAP Datasphere UI, we of course need to consume the forecast data in the planning model. To do that, we first need the results in the SAP Datasphere space. We create a view on top of the results table. We used a graphical view but depending on your preferences and skills, you may use an SQL view instead.  

  • Pull the results table from the DB user schema in the Sources tab. 

  • Add a calculation node to split the Entity column into regions and products again. Create two calculated columns (Product and Region) and use string functions.  The functions SUBSTR_BEFORE() and SUBSTR_AFTER() can be used to split a string using the first occurence of a specified pattern (in our case '|'  as the format of our Entity column is Product|Region). 

 Expression to derive product:

SUBSTR_BEFORE(Entity,'|')

Expression to derive region:

SUBSTR_AFTER(Entity,'|')
  •  Join the standard time dimension with day granularity to derive the calendar month from the date. Standard time tables and dimensions can be generated in Space Management (link).  

  • Add a projection and only keep the columns you need in the planning model. 
    • Calendar Month 
    • SalesRevenue 
    • Product 
    • Region 
  • Make sure to expose the view for consumption and select Fact as the Semantic Usage Type.  
  • Name the view and deploy.  

7. Adding the forecast result as live version in the seamless planning model 

We now move to SAP Analytics Cloud and add the forecast result to the seamless planning model as a live version.  

  • Connect external data source. 

  • Create a version to map the data into (or use an existing un-used version). 
  • Select the view. 
  • Map the columns. 
     
  • Preview the data. You see that we have a live connection to the forecast results in SAP Datasphere. So every time that the forecast is updated, it will be reflected in the planning model in real time! 

 

What (else) can/could you do with it?  

In SAP Analytics Cloud:  

  • You can display the live version data in the model data foundation and in tables, charts, etc. in stories. 
  • You can reference the live version data in model and story calculations as well as data actions (incl. advanced formulas). 
  • You cannot write back into the referenced views (or rather their underlying tables). But, you can copy the live version data into planning versions via copy/paste in the table, data actions and version management. 

In SAP Datasphere: 

  • You can of course leverage the forecast result in your views and analytic models and compare it to actuals, budgets, etc.  
  • You can run further transformations and calculations and report on the results or use them in planning.  
  • ‚Ä¶ 

 

Which new features can improve the workflow in the future? 

We are working on a couple of features that can make this scenario even better: 

  • Push data from SAP Datasphere into the seamless planning model via task chains:  
    Live versions are awesome. But, sometimes you want to use the prediction as a proposal and then edit it. You could copy the live version data into an editable version easily (see above) but with a push of data into the planning model, you could directly bring the data into an editable forecast version. That push could be nicely added to the same task chain that triggers the APL procedure. 
  • Trigger task chains from SAP Analytics Cloud:
    Task chains shall soon offer a public API for triggering task chain runs from outside of SAP Datasphere.
    We are getting ready on the SAP Analytics Cloud side to let you call this API via API steps in multi actions. With that, you could trigger the stored procedures from SAP Analytics Cloud.  
    Some day, we may have dedicated task chain steps in multi actions to ease this cross-orchestration. We also want to enable cross-orchestration in the opposite direction.  

 

Conclusion 

In this blogpost, Marc and I demonstrated how to integrate predictive forecast results from SAP HANA APL in a seamless planning model. We combined the power of SAP Datasphere, SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud to achieve that in a quite straight-forward architecture. You could achieve more complex scenarios, use PAL instead to tweak your prediction more etc. Or you could use data products from SAP BDC to get you started even quicker.  

We are looking forward to the future enhancements that shall improve such workflows and the overall integration of planning into SAP BDC! 

 

Learn More 

  • Seamless Planning - Product FAQ 
  • Seamless Planning ‚Äì Live Versions 
  • SAP HANA Automated Predictive Library (APL) 
  • SAP HANA Predictive Analysis Library (PAL)  
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Predictive Scenarios

entry.title: Connecting SAP Sales Cloud V2 to a Standalone SAP Analytics Cloud - A Practical Alternative
entry.content:
The Customer Challenge

A customer approached me with what seemed like a straightforward request: "We want to analyze our SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 data in SAP Analytics Cloud."

Their situation was common for mid-sized companies adopting SAP's CX portfolio:

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 was live and running well
  • SAP Analytics Cloud was licensed separately (not the embedded version)
  • No SAP BTP subscription yet, it wasn't part of the initial scope
  • No SAP Integration Suite same reason
  • No SAP Datasphere, they wanted to avoid another data platform

The goal was simple: import Accounts, Contacts, and Opportunities into SAC for custom dashboards that combined CX data with data from other sources

What SAP Officially Recommends

Before building anything custom, I researched SAP's official guidance. The recommended architecture for Sales Cloud V2 analytics integration involves:

  1. SAP Datasphere as a central data layer
  2. SAP Integration Suite for event-driven data replication
  3. SAP Advanced Event Mesh (optional but recommended) for resilience

SAP published a detailed two-part blog series on this: Event-Driven Data Integration from SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 to SAP Datasphere

This architecture is elegant and production-grade. It's also significant additional investment for a customer who just wants to run a few reports.

Cost Implications

The official path requires more than you might expect:

ComponentStatus for this Customer
SAP DatasphereNot licensed (‚Ç¨‚Ç¨‚Ç¨/month)
SAP Integration SuiteNot licensed (‚Ç¨‚Ç¨/month)
SAP BTP subscriptionNot available
Implementation effortSignificant (weeks)


For a customer with ~24,000 accounts who wants three dashboards, this felt like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

The Obvious First Attempt: SAC's Built-in Connectors

SAC has connectors for various SAP sources. Surely there's something for Sales Cloud?

Attempt 1: The "SAP Cloud for Customer" Connector

SAC includes a dedicated connector called "SAP Cloud for Customer" that works beautifully with the older C4C (Cloud for Customer) system. It connects to OData services like:

https://<tenant>/sap/c4c/odata/v1/c4codataapi/AccountCollection

The problem: Sales Cloud V2 is not C4C. So the OData connector won‚Äôt work:

Attempt 2: The Generic OData Connector

SAC also has a generic "OData Services" connector. Maybe that works?

The problem: Sales Cloud V2 doesn't expose OData endpoints. The APIs on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub are REST, not OData.

GET /sap/c4c/api/v1/account-service/accounts ‚Üê REST, not OData
GET /sap/c4c/api/v1/contact-service/contacts ‚Üê REST, not OData

Attempt 3: Live Connection

Sales Cloud V2 has embedded SAC capabilities. Could we establish a live connection?

The problem: The embedded analytics are designed for "embedded" use cases. Connecting a standalone SAC tenant to Sales Cloud V2 for custom reporting seems to be... let's say "not a focus area" right now.

I opened a support ticket to clarify the expected behavior and it was put in development after a little back and forth.

The Hidden Challenge: Real-Time vs. Import

At this point, I had to step back and discuss architecture with the customer.

Even if a direct connector existed, there are implications to consider:

 

ApproachProsCons
Live ConnectionAlways current dataQuery performance depends on source; cannot combine with other data sources easily
Import ConnectionFast queries; can blend with other sourcesData has latency; storage costs

The customer wanted to combine Sales Cloud V2 data with SAP S/4HANA data in the same dashboard. This essentially requires import connections for both sources, plus a data model in SAC that joins them.

Real-time was never really an option as they needed data at rest in SAP Analytics Cloud 

The Solution: A Lightweight REST-to-OData Proxy

Since the customer had:

  • No appetite for SAP Datasphere
  • No CPI license
  • A clear, limited scope (three entity types)
  • Tolerance for daily data refresh (not real-time)

I proposed building a thin proxy server that:

  1. Authenticates with Sales Cloud V2
  2. Fetches data via REST APIs
  3. Transforms responses to OData format
  4. Exposes endpoints that SAC can consume natively

Architecture

This sounds straightforward... until you start building it...

Challenge 1: The 999 vs. 1000 Mismatch

This one deserves its own section because it‚Äôs so unexpected.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 REST APIs have a maximum page size of 999 records. You can request $top=999, but not more.

SAP Analytics Cloud OData import has a minimum batch size of 1000 records.

Yes, you read that correctly. The source maxes out at 999. The target starts at 1000. I'll admit I stared at the logs for longer than I'd like to admit before I realized what was happening. The first 999 records imported perfectly. Then nothing. It took me a while to connect that SAC was waiting for a 1000-record batch that would never arrive.

The Solution

The proxy implements on-demand parallel fetching:

async function fetchAllRecords(entityType: string): Promise<any[]> {
  // Get first page to determine total count
  const firstPage = await fetchFromSalesCloud(entityType, {
    $top: 999,
    $skip: 0
  });
  
  if (firstPage.value.length < 999) {
    // All records fit in first page
    return firstPage.value;
  }
  
  // Calculate remaining pages and fetch in parallel
  const totalEstimate = firstPage.totalCount || 10000;
  const remainingPages = Math.ceil((totalEstimate - 999) / 999);
  
  const pagePromises = Array.from({ length: remainingPages }, (_, i) => 
    fetchFromSalesCloud(entityType, {
      $top: 999,
      $skip: 999 * (i + 1)
    })
  );
  
  const results = await Promise.all(pagePromises);
  return [firstPage.value, ...results.map(r => r.value)].flat();
}

The proxy fetches pages in parallel (not sequentially), caches the combined result, and serves it to SAC in appropriately sized batches. The cache has a configurable TTL (e.g., 1 hour) and automatically refreshes on the next request after expiry.

Challenge 2: Nested Objects and Flattening

Sales Cloud V2 returns nicely structured JSON with nested objects:

{
  "value": [{
    "accountId": "A001",
    "accountName": "ACME Corp",
    "primaryContact": {
      "contactId": "C001",
      "firstName": "John",
      "lastName": "Doe"
    },
    "addresses": [
      { "type": "BILL_TO", "city": "Berlin" },
      { "type": "SHIP_TO", "city": "Munich" }
    ]
  }]
}

SAC‚Äôs OData importer cannot handle this. The SAP Help documentation states clearly: Embedded Complex types are not supported.

The Solution

The proxy must flatten nested structures into separate entity sets:

/odata/Accounts         ‚Üí Flat account records
/odata/Contacts         ‚Üí Flat contact records  
/odata/AccountAddresses ‚Üí One row per address, linked by accountId

Challenge 3: REST APIs Behave Differently Than OData

Coming from the OData world, I expected certain conventions:

  • $filter for filtering
  • $select for field selection
  • $expand for related entities
  • Standardized metadata endpoint

Sales Cloud V2 REST APIs have their own conventions:

  • Different query parameter syntax
  • No $metadata endpoint
  • Pagination via custom headers or response properties

The proxy needs to translate between these worlds, implementing just enough OData semantics to satisfy SAC‚Äôs importer.

Challenge 4: The $skip 10,000 Limit

Just when you think you‚Äôve handled pagination, there‚Äôs another surprise waiting for datasets with more than 10,000 records.

Sales Cloud V2 returns an error if $skip is 10,000 or greater.

// This works
GET /accounts?$top=999&$skip=9000  ‚úÖ

// This fails
GET /accounts?$top=999&$skip=10000  ‚ùå Error!

So even if you‚Äôve cleverly worked around the 999 page size limit, you hit a wall at record 10,001. Simple offset-based pagination ($skip) just stops working.

The Solution

Instead of offset-based pagination, the proxy uses keyset pagination with $skiptoken:

// src/constants.ts
export const SC_MAX_SKIP = 10000;

// When approaching the skip limit, switch to skiptoken
async function fetchWithKeysetPagination(entityType: string): Promise<any[]> {
  const allRecords: any[] = [];
  let nextLink: string | null = buildInitialUrl(entityType);
  
  while (nextLink) {
    const response = await fetch(nextLink);
    const data = await response.json();
    
    allRecords.push(...data.value);
    
    // Use the skiptoken from the response for next page
    nextLink = data['@odata.nextLink'] || null;
  }
  
  return allRecords;
}

Keyset pagination uses a token (typically based on the last record‚Äôs ID or timestamp) rather than a numeric offset. This approach:

  • Has no upper limit on the number of records
  • Is actually more performant than large offsets
  • Is the pattern SAP recommends for large datasets

If you have more than 10,000 records in any entity, you must use $skiptoken-based pagination. Simple $skip won‚Äôt cut it.

Implementation Notes

Technology Choice

I built the proxy with:

  • Node.js + Fastify: Lightweight, fast, excellent TypeScript support
  • On-demand caching: No scheduled jobs; cache fills dynamically on first request
  • Docker deployment: Runs on any container platform (I use Coolify on a VPS)

This is a production-ready setup. The proxy has been running reliably for the customer with no issues.

Smart Caching: On-Demand Parallel Fetching

Rather than running scheduled batch jobs, the proxy uses an on-demand approach:

  1. First page served instantly: When SAC requests data, the proxy immediately returns the first page (up to 999 records) from Sales Cloud V2
  2. Parallel fetching in background: While SAC processes the first page, the proxy fetches remaining pages in parallel
  3. Cache populated for subsequent requests: By the time SAC requests page 2, the data is already cached
async function handleODataRequest(req: Request): Promise<Response> {
  // Check cache first
  if (cache.has(entityType) && !cache.isExpired(entityType)) {
    return serveFromCache(entityType, req.query);
  }
  
  // Fetch first page immediately
  const firstPage = await fetchPage(entityType, 0, 999);
  
  // Start parallel fetching of remaining pages (non-blocking)
  fetchRemainingPagesInBackground(entityType, firstPage.totalCount);
  
  // Return first page immediately
  return formatAsOData(firstPage);
}

This approach has several advantages:

  • No unnecessary background jobs: Data is only fetched when actually needed
  • Fast initial response: User doesn‚Äôt wait for full dataset
  • Self-healing cache: Expired cache automatically refreshes on next request

Optional: Deploying to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry

If you already have a BTP subscription with available credits, deploying there can make sense. You‚Äôre using infrastructure you‚Äôre already paying for. The migration is straightforward:

Standalone Setup Cloud Foundry Setup

Environment variables for credentialsDestination Service binding
In-memory cachePostgreSQL Hyperscaler Option (free tier available)
Direct HTTP endpointXSUAA + AppRouter

Why PostgreSQL if you move to BTP?

On a single-container deployment (VPS e.g. with Coolify), in-memory caching works perfectly. But Cloud Foundry typically runs multiple app instances for high availability. If you need persistence across instances, PostgreSQL Hyperscaler Option is the lightweight choice. It has a free tier (since November 2025) and requires no additional management.

The additional effort for Cloud Foundry deployment is roughly:

  • Add mta.yaml with service bindings (~1 hour)
  • Configure Destination Service for Sales Cloud V2 credentials (~30 min)
  • Add XSUAA for authentication (~1 hour)
  • Test and deploy (~2 hours)

Total: Less than one additional day if you decide BTP is the right fit.

Don‚Äôt just default to BTP just because it‚Äôs SAP. Evaluate what you already have and what makes sense for your situation. A ‚Ç¨5/month VPS running Docker might be exactly right for your use case.

OData Response Format

SAC expects OData V2or V4 responses. The minimum viable format:

{
  "d": {
    "results": [
      { "AccountID": "A001", "AccountName": "ACME Corp", ... },
      { "AccountID": "A002", "AccountName": "Globex", ... }
    ]
  }
}

Plus a $metadata endpoint returning EDMX that describes your entity types.

Authentication

Sales Cloud V2 supports:

  • Basic Authentication (simplest for server-to-server)
  • OAuth 2.0 (more secure, recommended for production)

The proxy stores credentials securely and handles token refresh for OAuth.

Results

After implementing the proxy:

  • SAC successfully imports Accounts, Contacts, and Opportunities
  • Data refreshes nightly via scheduled import
  • Customer can blend CX data with S/4HANA data in unified dashboards
  • No additional SAP platform licenses required
  • Total implementation time: ~2 days

When This Approach Makes Sense

The right solution depends on what you have and what you need. Here‚Äôs how I think about it:

A lightweight proxy makes sense when:

  • Limited scope (specific entities, not the entire data model)
  • Import/batch refresh is acceptable (not real-time requirements)
  • You don‚Äôt have Datasphere or CPI licensed and don‚Äôt need them for other use cases
  • You want to validate the integration quickly before investing in bigger infrastructure

Datasphere + CPI makes sense when:

  • You need event-driven, near real-time data replication
  • You‚Äôre integrating many entity types with complex relationships
  • You already have Datasphere or CPI licensed then use what you‚Äôre paying for
  • You have a broader data strategy where Datasphere is the central hub anyway

The key question: What do you already have, and does this use case justify adding more?

SAP‚Äôs platforms are excellent, no question! But sometimes a focused solution that solves exactly your problem is better than pulling in the big guns for a straightforward requirement.

Lessons Learned

1. Don‚Äôt Assume SAP Products Integrate Seamlessly

Sales Cloud V2 and SAC are both modern SAP cloud products. The integration gap exists because V2‚Äôs move away from OData wasn‚Äôt accompanied by a new native SAC connector (yet).

2. Check API Patterns Before Committing to Architecture

The shift from OData to REST in Sales Cloud V2 is documented, but easy to miss if you‚Äôre coming from C4C experience. Always verify on api.sap.com.

3. Test with Realistic Data Volumes

The 999/1000 mismatch only surfaces with more than 999 records. Demo systems with 50 accounts work fine. Production breaks.

4. Use What You Have, Validate What You Need

The official architecture is powerful. But if you don‚Äôt already have Datasphere and CPI licensed, ask yourself: does this specific use case justify adding them? Sometimes a focused solution that solves exactly your problem is the right call. You can always scale up later if requirements grow.

What‚Äôs Next?

I‚Äôve published a reference implementation on GitHub that demonstrates the core patterns:

  • REST-to-OData transformation
  • Parallel fetching with caching
  • The 999‚Üí1000 batch bridging logic
  • Keyset pagination with $skiptoken for large datasets (>10k records)

üëâ GitHub: SAP Sales Cloud V2 OData Proxy

A note on scope: The repository shows how the solution works, but doesn‚Äôt include everything from my production implementation. Some aspects are tied to specific client configurations that I can‚Äôt share. If you‚Äôre facing a similar challenge and want help getting to production faster, feel free to reach out.

If you‚Äôve built something similar or found a better approach I‚Äôd love to hear about it in the comments.

entry.title: Filling the gab between BW and Datasphere (a bit): Implementing a few standard variables
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • How to install:
  • How were they implemented:
  • Example: Analytical Models
  • Implemented Variables
  • 0CALDAY: Calendar Day
  • 0CALMONTH: Calendar Year / Month
  • 0CALQUARTER:
  • 0CALWEEK:
  • 0CALYEAR:

Introduction

Welcome to the first blog in a series where I'll try my best to close up some of the functionality gabs between the old SAP BW system and  SAP Datasphere.
With the end of life for the old SAP BW systems in sight, companies and developers have been diving deep into SAP Datasphere, to build new, exciting solutions, in addition to migrating existing reports. 

Personally, I've been involved with several Datasphere implementations now, and one thing I have found myself missing a lot was the standard Exit variables for things like "Current month", "Current year" and so on. 

To make my life, and hopefully yours as well, I've recreated a set of the old date / calendar variables.
All the views are bundled in a nice package, which you can download from this GitHub repo. 

How to install:

Note: Your Datasphere tenant does not need to be connected to the Content Network for this to work. 

One the package is installed, you may, or may not, need to change the source of the view 2VR_CALENDER_WRAPPER, which is the basis of all the other views. 
This was simply done to make sure that even if your space does not contain the Time Objects, you only have to remap 1 object. 

  1. Go to this GitHub Repo and download the package
  2. Go to your Datasphere tenant and select "Import":
  3. Click Upload and select the package downloaded in step 1.
  4. After the import is complete click the package:
  5. Under "Import Options", map the space:

     

  6. And click "Import". 
  7. (Certain cases): If the view "SAP.TIME.VIEW_DIMENSION_DAY" is not present in the target space open the view 2VR_CALENDER_WRAPPER and replace the source.

 

How were they implemented:

All the views are implemented as SQL views, and only return a single column, depending on the kind of view, rather than an interval, which some SAP BW variables might give. The reason for that is explained in the example below. 

All views have an input parameter, IP_OFFSET, which takes an integer, and will offset the result by one "unit" of time. 
So the CALYEAR views will offset one year at a time, the month views will offset one month at the time, and so on. 

Example: Analytical Models

In Datasphere, an Analytical Model is the final (kind of, that's not important now) step in the data modelling process. 
In your analytical model, you can define different kind of variables, that allows you to derive a value from a view, or a dynamic default. 
Note:  Deriving select options and intervals are not supported. 

In the above example, the user will be prompted to fill in an interval, but will only derive the first value:

If you want an interval, you'll need "Multiple single values".

In the above example, we've provided a view that returns three values, which will act as an interval.
Note: We have also provided the value -1 for the offset.

Which means all the values, 202601, 202512, 202511, and 202510 is offset by -1:

Implemented Variables

I've created variables for the following date objects:

  • 0CALDAY: Date (YYYYMMDD)
  • 0CALMONTH: Cal. Year / Month (YYYYMM)

entry.title: Building a Graph Native AI Chatbot on SAP BTP
entry.content:
The true intelligence and accuracy of an enterprise AI chatbot depends on one thing, Data Access. While most chatbots rely on standard API calls to fetch information, it hits a wall when dealing with complex, interconnected business logic.

The Problem: Chatbot's rely on API calls to extract data from source system. APIs are designed for transactions and not data exploration. For example, if a user asks, 'Show me the total revenue impact of C4C service tickets related to S/4HANA orders delayed by supplier issues,' .

A traditional chatbot is stuck. It would need to orchestrate a number of cross-system OData calls, join the data in memory, and calculate the results often resulting in high latency or timeouts.

The Solution: SAP HANA Graph

The better approach is by combining the LLM with the Graph Schema in SAP HANA, we can bypass these limitations entirely. In this blog, I will show you how to build a Graph-Native Agentic AI that understands your data relationships intuitively.

Instead of viewing data as API endpoints, we model it as a Property Graph. Here, the business entities (like Customers, Sales Orders, Service Tickets, Products) are represented as Vertex(Nodes) and their relations are the Edges.

Deep-Node Traversals:

The graph allows the chatbot to traverse relationships instantly. In a single query it can hop from a Customer node -->Sales Order node -->Line Item node --> Product node, collect the necessary data and send it to the LLM which is then sent to the user.

The graph engine natively supports aggregations(SUM,COUNT) directly in the database layer during node traversal

We can physically link a C4C Service Ticket node to a S/4HANA Sales Order node. The graph schema identifies only the data relation and not the system of origin.

Representation of interconnected Business Objects that form a graph.

 

Let's See it in Action - Demo Video

Conceptualizing a graph traversal can be difficult, so let‚Äôs look at how the chatbot handles a query involving Sales Cloud scenario:

Why I chose Property Graph?

  • vs. Knowledge Graphs: While Knowledge Graphs focus on semantics and inference (great for unstructured data), Property Graphs focus on structure and attributes, which fits enterprise data better.
  • Rich Context: Relationship between Business Objects carry properties. For example, a relationship between a Customer and a Product isn't just a relationship link, it contains transaction details like: CUSTOMER --> BOUGHT {ProductID: 10005824, Date: 20/01/2026, Quantity: 5, Price: $100} --> PRODUCT
  • Mathematical Aggregations: Property Graph engines are optimized to perform aggregations (Sum Revenue, Count Tickets, Avg) on the fly during data traversal. 
  • Accuracy: We rely on strict graph schema definitions to ensure the LLM generates accurate, hallucination free queries.

Architecture:

To enable this real-time graph agent, I implemented a robust data fabric on SAP BTP.

Real-time data fabric

We utilize SAP Datasphere to act as the pipeline for data source & replication. By replicating the raw tables into SAP HANA via Datasphere, we ensure the data is real-time. Once the data is replicated to HANA, the Graph Workspace is created on top of these tables, defining the vertexes (nodes) and edges (relationships) virtually.

Handling Federated Data Scenarios

In cases where data cannot be not replicated to SAP HANA(volume constraints), the architecture adapts seamlessly. The Graph LLM retains its logic and identifies the necessary nodes(vertices) and query parameters based on the user prompt. Instead of generating a openCypher query these parameters are mapped to optimized OData calls to the source system. This ensures a streamlined, real-time federation strategy that shows the precision of a graph traversal.

Schema Injection

The graph schema(the definition of Nodes and Edges) is injected to LLM at run time. Based on the user query the LLM will first identify the nodes, data traversal path and the logic.

For the query: ‚ÄúWho are my top 5 customers by sales volume who also have open critical tickets?‚Äù

The LLM determines the execution plan:

  • Nodes Identified: BusinessPartner (Customer), SalesOrder, ServiceRequest
  • Traversal Paths:
    • BusinessPartner --> SalesOrder (To calculate volume)
    • BusinessPartner <-- ServiceRequest (To find the open tickets)
  • Filters Applied:
    • ServiceRequest.LifeCycleStatus = 'Open'
    • ServiceRequest.Priority = 'Critical'
  • Aggregation: Sum of SalesOrder.NetAmount grouped by Customer.
  • Ranking: Order by Sum Descending, Limit 5.

openCypher Query Generation

Once the LLM identifies the graph query plan, the actual openCypher query is generated programmatically using python. I did not use LLM here as the openCypher wrapped in HANA is tricky and requires precise syntax.

The openCypher query is executed directly against the SAP HANA Graph engine and the result is passed to the LLM to generate a natural language summary.

Transactional Updates (Write Scenarios)

For maintaining transaction data, the Agentic AI brings in a mandatory human-in-the-loop confirmation step before any data is written via a POST request. You can see the technical implementation steps for this human intervention logic in my earlier blog post.

User Interface & Deployment

The core Chatbot agent is deployed on SAP BTP. For the front end, I utilized SAP Build Apps to create a clean, low-code user interface. The app connects to the BTP agent and provides a seamless chat experience for the business user.

Conclusion

By moving from API loops to Graph Traversals, we unlock the true potential of Enterprise AI. We get the speed of database-level aggregation with the flexibility of natural language processing.

Reference:

Refer this blog to understand about the implementation of Agentic AI Chatbot using LangGraph - The power of AI Agents: My Journey with LangGraph

entry.title: How to call AS ABAP from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

For communication between SAP systems based on AS ABAP, RFC connections are the standard method. For example, when extracting from SAP ERP, the SAP BW system first launches the extractor in the source system via a BW->ERP RFC connection. The source system then returns the data collected by the extractor via an ERP->BW RFC connection.

For SAP Datasphere (hereinafter referred to as DSP), the natural successor to this approach is the BW Bridge use. However, not all projects justify using BW Bridge in terms of system landscape, architecture, project scope, and implementation costs.

This blog proposes an approach that allows DSP to execute code in a system running AS ABAP (without using BW Bridge). We will call this code as target code. The idea is to leverage CDS functionality known such as Virtual Elements. A Virtual Element is a field in a CDS View Entity, specifically defined using annotations. This field is not retrieved from the database table level and is not calculated by formulas within the CDS View itself. Instead, accessing the CDS View triggers execution of specialized ABAP code that implements the calculation logic for this field. For BW specialists this may remember well-known virtual characteristics and key figures. On the other hand, the CDS View is an object accessible to DSPs, for example, as a Source for Data Flow. Thus, by running Data Flow Run on the DSP side, we automatically initiate execution of the code that calculates the Virtual Element values ‚Äã‚Äãin AS ABAP. We can, in turn, include calls of any desired programs, functional modules, or class methods to this code‚Äîthat is, achieve the execution of the target code.

Unfortunately, this approach has one significant drawback that complicates its implementation: Virtual elements are only function within OData services generated from CDS views. This means that we cannot use connections of type SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP ABAP, or SAP BW on the DSP side. You will need to create a Generic OData connection.

Implementation plan is following:

  1. Create a CDS View Entity in S/4HANA using a Virtual Element.
  2. Create an ABAP class that implements the calculation of this Virtual Element. The class code will include the target code call.
  3. Register and test the OData Service.
  4. Review the permissions required for the technical user on whose behalf the connection will be made. These permissions should be broader than the standard permissions for connections of type SAP S/4HANA On-Premise or SAP ABAP.
  5. Notes regarding creating a Generic OData connection in DSP.
  6. Create a simple Data Flow in DSP using the OData connection to the created CDS View. Running this Data Flow (manually, scheduled, or as part of a Task Chain) will trigger our target code in S/4HANA.

CDS View Entity with Virtual Element

We will create a dummy CDS View. It doesn't need to provide any meaningful data. We only need the ability to add a Virtual Element field to it. Therefore, as an example, we'll use a selection from the TKA01 (Controlling Areas) table. Typically, a single Controlling Area with a value of 1000 is used. Based on this assumption, we'll create the CDS View. Of course, you can use other selections that are guaranteed to return a single record in your system. The following code is proposed:

@EndUserText.label: 'CDS Virtual Element Test'
@analytics.dataCategory: #DIMENSION
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@vdm.viewType: #BASIC
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations:true
@ObjectModel.usageType.serviceQuality: #A
@ObjectModel.usageType.sizeCategory: #S
@ObjectModel.usageType.dataClass: #MASTER
@analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@analytics.dataExtraction.delta.changeDataCapture.automatic: true
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities:[#EXTRACTION_DATA_SOURCE]
@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@odata.publish: true

define view entity Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM as select from tka01
{
key kokrs,
substring( cast( tstmp_current_utctimestamp() as abap.char(17) ), 1, 8 ) as dat,
@ObjectModel.readOnly: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElement: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC'
cast('' as abap.sstring( 1 )) as flag
}
where kokrs = '1000'
  •  The annotation at line 13 enables access to the CDS View via the OData Service.
  • The ‚Äòdat‚Äô field is added as a simple log: to see the date of the last calculation run.
  • The ‚Äòflag‚Äô field of the Virtual Element type is defined at line 22. It has the simplest form of a flag field. By default, as can be seen from the code, this field is empty. However, upon completion of calculations on the AS ABAP side, it will be filled with the value 'X'. This flag confirms at DSP side the successful completion of ABAP calculations.
  • The annotations at lines 19-21 define the "flag" field as a Virtual Element. In particular, the @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy annotation specifies the name of the ABAP class that should calculate the ‚Äòflag‚Äô field.

When you initially activate this code, you'll receive, in particular, two warnings. For line 13 the system reports that the corresponding OData service is not active. For line 21 the system reports that the corresponding class doesn't exist. In the next steps, we'll resolve these issues.

If we use the context menu command 'Open With -> Data Preview' on our CDS View at this point, the result will be as follows:Here the 'kokrs' and 'dat' fields are populated using standard CDS syntax. The virtual 'flag' field is left blank.

Creation of ABAP Class implementing our calculations

A Virtual Element calculation implementing  class must use two standard interfaces: IF_SADL_EXIT –∏ IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ:

class ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC definition
public
final
create public .

public section.

interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT .
interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ .
protected section.
private section.
ENDCLASS.

Second of these interfaces has two standard methods. A detailed description of these methods and their parameters can be found in the official documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_BW4HANA/cc0c305d2fab47bd808adcad3ca7ee9d/4b5e56ec6f28453f81a...

In our example, the following code is proposed for the GET_CALCULATION_INFO method:

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~get_calculation_info.
IF iv_entity = 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM'.
"Here we'll list which fields of CDS View will be used in virtual element calculation
IF line_exists( it_requested_calc_elements[ table_line = 'FLAG' ] ).
APPEND 'KOKRS' TO et_requested_orig_elements.
ENDIF.
ELSE.
" Potential errors should be processed by public constants,
" described in exceptional class, inherited from CX_SADL_EXIT.
" For example, if CDS View is unknown:

RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE zcx_ds_virt_elem_exceptions EXPORTING textid = zcx_ds_virt_elem_exceptions=>c_entity_not_known.
ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.

Errors occurring during execution of the class described above must be handled using system messages. For this purpose, public constants will be created in a separate exception class. The class must be a child of the standard CX_SADL_EXIT class. An example of such an exception class is provided in the official documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_NETWEAVER_AS_ABAP_751_IP/cc0c305d2fab47bd808adcad3ca7ee9d/8cf451799476...  

As we can see, after specifying the parent class, a small constructor override is required. Each error is then declared as a public constant attribute. Naturally, such attribute contains a system message, previously defined in the Message Class relevant to the task.

Since our CDS View is designed to be as simple as possible, the IT_REQUESTED_CALC_ELEMENTS table will contain a single row with the ‚ÄòFLAG‚Äô field. The ET_REQUESTED_ORIG_ELEMENTS table of regular source fields also contains only one record with the ‚ÄòKOKRS‚Äô field.

Let's move on to the CALCULATE method:

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~calculate.
CHECK NOT it_original_data IS INITIAL.
DATA lit_calculated_data TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF z_cds_virt_elem WITH DEFAULT KEY.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING it_original_data TO lit_calculated_data.

LOOP AT lit_calculated_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_calculated_data>).
"Here we need to add a call to the code that we wanted to initiate from the DSP side.
"For example, we can submit some program:
" SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN.
<lfs_calculated_data>-flag = 'X'. "Formal flag of the calculation readiness
EXIT. "Additional guarantee that calculation will be performed only once
ENDLOOP.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING lit_calculated_data TO ct_calculated_data.
ENDMETHOD.

Our CDS View is intentionally designed to return exactly one record. This means that in the CALCULATE method, the IT_ORIGINAL_DATA table also contains exactly one record. Consequently, the LOOP/ENDLOOP loop will only be executed once, and the target code will also be called only once.

After the ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC class is activated, the warning on line 21 of our CDS View code will disappear.

OData Service activation

Our CDS View annotation specifies that it can be accessed via an OData Service. When we activate the CDS code, the corresponding OData Service will be created but not activated. Activation must be performed manually in the /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE transaction. The OData Service name consists of the name of our CDS View followed by the _CDS suffix. In our example, the resulting name is Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS.

Click the 'Add Service' button:

 An ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô window will appear. Enter Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS as the technical name, and select LOCAL from the list in the 'System Alias' field. Then click 'Get Services'. A line with our service should appear:

 Select the row with service description and press the ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô button:In the 'Package Assignment' field, specify the appropriate package for subsequent import of developed objects to the production system. In the 'ICF Node' section, select the 'SAP Gateway OData V2' setting. An important setting is the 'Enable OAuth for Service' checkbox. Check with your BASIS Team to determine whether OAuth will be used when connecting the DSP to the ABAP system. If so, enable this checkbox. After confirming the settings, service activation will begin. Upon completion, the following message will appear: 

Now you need to return to the main transaction window and filter the newly activated service in the list:

 Check the traffic light in the 'Status' field (the leftmost field in the ICF Nodes section). If it's yellow, select the drop-down list from the 'ICF Node' button directly above it and execute the 'Activate' command:

The window for selecting a package for importing activated objects into production will appear again:

After this, the traffic light will change to green. You can now test the service by clicking the 'SAP Gateway Client' button:

 By default, the test transaction specifies a URI that reads the service description:

But we're interested in what entities this service can provide. This can be found by clicking the 'Entity Set' button:

Here we see that the service can read data for CDS View Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM. By double-clicking this name, we can change the URI:

If you now click the 'Execute' button, data will be read from the CDS View Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM via the OData Service. This is precisely the operation that should trigger the calculation of the 'flag' field via the ABAP class described above. If you need to study or debug this class, you can set breakpoints there before clicking 'Execute'. The calculation results will be presented here in XML format:Here you can see that the 'flag' field is filled with the value 'X'. This means that the CALCULATE method was executed along with the target code call.

System user authorizations

When creating a DSP connection to an ABAP system, a special user of the System type is used. Typically, the BASIS Team assigns this user a standard set of permissions sufficient for connections of SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP ABAP, or SAP BW types. Experience has shown that a Generic OData connection requires a number of additional permissions.

First, you need to add authorizations to launch the created OData Service. This is the S_SERVICE authorization object. Editing it differs from most standard authorization objects. After adding the object to the role profile, click the edit button for the SRV_NAME field. In the window that appears, select 'TADIR Service' from the Type drop-down list, which will display a list of services allowed to launch:

We need to add two types of objects for our service: IWSG and IWSV. First, select the appropriate type from the list in the 'Object Type' column. Then, use the search (for example, by pressing F4) in the 'Object Name' column. In both cases, you can use the name of our service (i.e. -  Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS) to search for the desired value:The name of the object being searched consists of the service name and the ordinal number of the active version of this service (four digits). For the first version of service in our example, the IWSG type value is 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS_0001', and the IWSV type value is 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS 0001'.

After saving the selected values, you will see that the value 'HT' is automatically added to the SRV_TYPE field. Thus, the S_SERVICE authorizations have been added and the values ‚Äã‚Äãspecified.

It is also important to note that specific authorizations may be required, which depend on the specific target code you want to run in the CALCULATE method described above. For example, if you plan to use a command like 'SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN' to launch a program, you will need the corresponding authorizations in the S_PROGRAM object. If the target code performs, for example, calculations related to the FI module, the system user may require authorizations specific to that module. If the target code accesses the contents of database tables, authorizations in the S_TABU_DIS and S_TABU_NAM objects may be required. And so on. Most likely, during the OData service testing phase (as described in the previous section), you will need to collaborate with the BASIS Team to monitor missing authorizations and add them to the system user's roles. The simplest solution is to temporarily (and only in the development system!) change the user type from system to dialog. In this case, you can log in to the SAP GUI with this user's login and manually run OData service testing while simultaneously monitoring the authorizations being checked.

The security issue of assigning such non-typical authorizations to a system user is mitigated by the fact that this user is created only to connect DSP to the ABAP system and cannot be used for manual data access, like a dialog user.

DSP OData Connection

Creating a Generic OData connection should be performed by BASIS Team specialists, as the required settings depend on the system landscape used in your specific project, as well as the security settings applied (for example, whether OAuth is enabled). Here's an example of the settings used in our project:The address entered in the ‚ÄòURL‚Äô field ends with the technical name of our OData service. Therefore, a separate connection will need to be created for each OData service.

In the ‚ÄòVersion‚Äô field, V2 is selected. This is because we specified OData V2 when activating the service above and didn't have the option to select V4:

The example also shows that OAuth is used. That's why the corresponding checkbox was enabled earlier when activating the service:

At the bottom of the connection settings window, click the ‚ÄòShow Advanced Properties‚Äô button:

Here you need to specify for the OData service the client number of the ABAP system we are connecting to:

 

DSP Data Flow to use OData connection and trigger the target code

We need to create a Data Flow with our OData service as a source. To do this, open Data Builder (in the same Space where you created OData service connection). In the left pane, select the 'Sources' tab and open the 'Connections' folder:

If all connection settings and system user authorizations were configured correctly, you will see the connection, and when you expand it, you will see the name of our CDS View:

The icon next to the CDS View is the same as for a regular table. You can drag and drop this View into the Data Flow being created. It will be automatically recognized as a Source. At this step, you can select the 'Preview Data' command for this table:

The result should look like this:

The presence of an 'X' in the 'flag' field means that the target code has been executed on the ABAP system side. If the target code execution takes a long time, you will also notice the delay when viewing it in the DSP.

As a final step, you need to complete the Data Flow by adding the target table to it, which in this case only serves as a dummy. Save the Data Flow and deploy it.

Result

Now you can initiate execution of the target code in the ABAP system in any way convenient for you: by manually starting the Data Flow, scheduling it, or including the Data Flow in a Task Chain.

 

 

Note: Data Preview is not working for Virtual Element

As a result of our implementation, OData Service is activated and implementing ABAP class exist for our Virtual Element. And  we can repeat attempt of CDS data preview in ABAP Development Tools (CDS editor context menu command 'Open With -> Data Preview'). Unfortunately, result will be the same: field ‚Äòflag‚Äô is empty: 

This is explained by the fact that the Virtual Element calculation is performed only when accessing the CDS through OData Service.
